Inspector Harison's report on the schools in the Carlton Agency.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I beg to submit the following report in connection with a visitation to the schools in the Carlton Agency. There are 7 day schools included in this Agency and I visited them all, with the exception of that at Montreal Lake and am reporting upon them in the order of visitation.

ROUND PLAIN DAY SCHOOL.

This school is under the auspices of the United Church. The Rev. J. C. Meek, B.A., is in charge as teacher. He is well qualified. There are 7 Indian children enrolled, 3 boys and 5 girls. That is all that are of school age on the reserve at the present time. It is expected that 4 more may attend in the spring. Of these, 3 attend every day, 2 are fairly regular, and 2 are irregular in their attendance. The children were warmly clad and looked well nourished. They go home for their mid-day meal.

For recreation a toboggan slide is provided for the winter. They have a swing and a football for the warmer weather. I noted that the swing requires a new rope.

This school was re-opened, not only for the Indians, but to provide schooling for the neighbouring white settlers. The school is built of logs and although an old building, it is fairly comfortable. Some repairs are required.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
ROUND PLAIN DAY SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

are required which can be done during the summer holidays. The cost will be about $20.00. Being a log building and old, certain repairs are necessary each year.

The teacher's residence is a neat frame cottage.

W. Morrison
Superintendent of Indian Affairs
DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE,

REGINA, SASK., April 15th, 1929.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I beg to submit herewith Inspector Murison's report on the various schools in the Carlton Agency.

You will notice that the Round Plain School is an old log building, and while it is comfortable, it requires some repairs which could be attended to during the summer at a cost of about $20.00. The Agent has placed an item of $200.00 in the Estimates to look after unforeseen repairs to schools in the agency, part of which could be used for this purpose.

Conditions at the Little Red River Day School appear to be satisfactory. I note that the teacher's residence is a small cottage divided into a kitchen, dining-room and two bedrooms, and that there are no porches. There is nothing in the Estimates to provide for a summer kitchen, and I should have thought the Agent would have inserted an item for this had he thought it necessary. I think we should allow $75.00 for a fence to enclose the school and make a small pasture for the teacher's driving horses.

It is hard to know what to recommend at the Sturgeon Lake Day School in order to get these children to school. It is a pity they could not be sent to a boarding school. The teacher's residence will be considered if the amount asked for in the Estimates is allowed.

-It seems-

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
It seems to me there is room for a change at the Big River Day School, but I do not know what to suggest. The school has just been started and perhaps another year will make it clear as to what should be done. I hesitate to recommend a new building for the teacher. However, if one could be built of logs for four or five hundred dollars it might be a good investment. I doubt if Mr. Settee is the man for this job, in fact I do not think he is.

The Sandy Bay School seems to be doing good work. It is an old, established place. I notice that 12 additional desks are asked for at this institution. These could be supplied if the Department would grant the authority. We could provide ladders for the school residence if the Department wish to grant them. I do not know what the cost would be, but probably three ladders could be supplied for $75.00.

You will note that the Mistawasis Day School is being taught by Miss Sadie McQueen, who took up her duties on the 26th of November last. She appears to be working under very unsatisfactory conditions. My own opinion is that she has too much to do, and there is an open quarrel on here which should not be allowed to continue. Miss McQueen should be encouraged and I think if the matter set out in the Inspector's report were brought to the attention of the proper authorities there would be a change made before long.

Yours very truly,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.
Ottawa, April 23rd, 1929.

Sir:

I have been directed to acknowledge receipt of your No. 303-11 of the 15th instant, enclosing Mr. Inspector Murison's report on his inspection of the various schools in the Carlton Agency. These reports have been read with interest and it is noted that progress is being made in the work at the schools.

With reference to the Inspector's report regarding the repairs required to the Round Plain Combined White and Indian School, you may arrange during the coming summer to have the repairs required made to this building. It is noted that the Inspector estimates this work will cost approximately $20.

You are being written in separate communications relative to the requirements at the other schools in the Carlton Agency.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

Oct. 4, 1934.

Dear Mr. Davis,

Re 2230-8-31, the Department letter regarding repairing the residence furnace and plastering the school.

The agreement between the Church and the Department when this school and mission was reopened in QEW/1922, was that the Church should repair and own the residence, while the Department of Indian Affairs would repair and own the school.

I hardly expected that the Department would consider it was its responsibility to repair the furnace, but during the past eleven years, it has replastered the school three times, and supplied the lumber for the floor. The local Trustee Board laid it. So I hope that the Department will reconsider the plastering of the school. I had the work done and paid the Indian, Tom Standing, who did the work, $5.00.

The Department has always been generous and helpful, so I am sure that there must be some slight mistake, perhaps by a clerk at Ottawa. But I do not know just how to get it rectified.

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]

Ottawa, October 23, 1934.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 15th instant, regarding the arrangements made with the authorities of the United Church of Canada for the upkeep of the school building and teacher's residence on the Sioux Wahpaton reserve, No. 94A.

In this connection I have to say that, in April, 1922, the Department agreed with the authorities of the above named Church to reopen a school for the benefit of the Indian children on the Reserve and the white children in the neighbourhood. At that time, a school district had been formed by the white settlers and trustees appointed. This school was to be carried on in the old school building, which was the property of the Church. The Church authorities agreed to hand this building over to the Government, on the understanding that the Department would incur the expenditure required in making the necessary repairs to place it in a suitable condition for classroom work. Since that time, the Department has incurred expenditures in carrying out certain repairs. This school was to be conducted as a combined Indian and White school, under the joint auspices of the Department and the Board of Trustees for the district. The school building and grounds belong to the Department.

With reference to the residence used by the teacher, I have to say that this building belongs to the Church authorities, and the Department is not responsible for any part of the costs of upkeep.

We were in error, in our letter to you dated August 16th, last, in stating that the Department does not own the school building.

You may, therefore, incur an expenditure in the purchase of the lime required in plastering up holes and white-washing the school building and for the labour required in doing the work - the total cost of which should not exceed your estimate of $8.30. Please forward an account, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the cost of the lime and labour.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

R. S. Davis, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Leask, Sask.

Sir,

The Indians dwelling here are anxious to have a school, as they do not care generally to send their children to Lac la Ronge. There are 16 children of school age on the north side, and 7 on the south side; and these live here for the most part, I understand, throughout the year. The river is half a mile wide here, and a number of the children would have to be taken across daily by canoe.

The usefulness of a school here would depend largely on the character and qualifications of the teacher that might be put in charge; and it would not be possible to secure a well qualified teacher for a day school here except at very high pay. Besides, a day school would, at the best, supply the educational needs of less than half the band. Sooner or later a boarding school will be required here, and it is probable that it would not be advisable to expend money on a school here until the question of the establishment of a boarding school is considered.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

In connection with the opening of a day school at Stanley I have the honour to state that while the proposed site for the school will be convenient to the larger part of the band there will still be some whose homes are at some distance. There are a few families, in particular, who live on the side of the river opposite to the Mission, adjacent to which the school is to be located. The river at this point is about three-quarters of a mile wide, and children who are brought across in canoe in the morning cannot very well return home until evening. There will, I think, be about one-third of the children who cannot conveniently return to their homes at noon; and as it would be a substantial benefit to the Indians generally and a help in maintaining a full and regular attendance, I would recommend that a noon meal corresponding in some measure to that of the improved day schools be served to all the children who attend.

It would be necessary to make provision for 30, as there will at times be quite that number in attendance. The knives, forks and spoons can be supplied from the industrial school here after its closing; but cups and soup plates would have to be purchased, as there are very few of these on hand here that would be worth the cost of their transport to Stanley.

there were only two sacks of flour. This has been distributed and we have had to procure two sacks more. There is still a little bacon, tea, sugar & rice on hand, but these provisions will all soon be used. We have likewise had to procure cooking utensils, cups, plates, spoons etc.

I had to pay for lumber for decks & roofs and likewise a carpenter's wages in making the above. I have so far spent close on $35.00 in procuring the above.

The Indians are much interested in the school and I hope the Department will supply all necessary requirements.

We have only a monthly mail and it will take fully three months before I can receive a reply from you.

Yours respectfully,

Dear Sir,

Thank you for your letter of Jan. 21st (14-72) informing me of increased remuneration. You also inform me, that the Government will no longer continue the monthly payments of $10.00 to the Indian woman who prepares the mid-day meals and that the older pupils must do that work. Maybe the Gov't. is unacquainted with conditions existing on this Reserve.

At the present time there are only two Indian families residing here. The others left last fall and will not return until the end of May. During their absence who is to look after these children? With a Gov't. house attached to the Mission, I, with the help of the older girls could manage well, but there is no house close and the children are housed and mothered by the woman who prepares the noon meals. At the present time eight are living there and these, with the children of the two families previously mentioned and non-treaty children, total eighteen in daily attendance at School. Young girls cannot be left to live alone on this Reserve and if Mrs. Maggie Bear is removed it will mean closing down the School. The Chief and all are strongly against this step being taken, as they greatly appreciate the School and hope you will use your influence in retaining the services of this widow woman. This house is unsuitable or I would house the children here. Even if the girls did prepare the mid-day meals where would they sleep? They are so happy and doing such good work that I would be sorry to see the School closed. Life would indeed be quiet in this isolated place without the school children. My husband, who is Missionary in charge here, also asks you to do your utmost in the matter and to allow Mrs. Bear to remain until the end of May.

Thanking you for an early reply.

Believe me,

Yours truly,

(Sgd.) Mabel Morris.

Right Reverend Sir,-

I beg to inform Your Lordship that Mr. Commissioner Graham, Regina, has forwarded the resignation of Mrs. Mabel Morris, teacher of the Stanley Indian Day School, from the end of the present month. The teacher states that she is leaving to reside in England during the coming winter, and, if no other teacher can be found in the meantime she will take up her work again on her return in the spring.

It is considered that it would be in the best interests of the Indian children to have the school continue and the Department has, therefore, to request that Your Lordship will be good enough to nominate a suitable person as teacher to succeed Mrs. Morris. The name of the teacher selected by you, together with the age, qualifications, experience, etc., should be forwarded for the approval of the Department.

The Department would like you to be good enough to give this matter your early attention and endeavour to secure a teacher, as it is not desired to have this school remain closed longer than is necessary.

Dear Mr. Lean,

As by my request of 24th requesting me & endeavoring to secure a teacher for the Stanley Ind. Day School to succeed Mr. Morris. I should be glad to nominate a suitable person if I could find one; but it seems impossible now so these days as the salary hitherto offered. I have been trying.

1. The teacher must be found at a distance from Stanley. The cost of getting there is great. Who will pay this? I can not. If the teacher pays it, it will take many months salary.

2. Mr. Morris would like to remain in his retired, & he has done the work capably. To send a teacher for 6 or 9 months would be an enormous expense for the work done.

3. The winter is the hardest time to get a teacher to go such a place, & the worst time for any good results in the way of attendance. I was there lately, & I understand that if the Indians did not hear of a teacher at once, many children would go away for winter.

4. Please tell me what you think of the matter: What salary you are prepared to offer, & whether you will pay the travelling expenses thereafter.

Yours faithfully,

J.T. Saskatchewan

Dear Sir,-

I am writing to you on behalf of the Chief
and Band of this Reserve, re the school rations and pay
of the Woman preparing meals:

Firstly - the children are allowed a mid-
day meal only, consisting of 4 oz. flour per head, bacon,
tea etc. maybe the Department is ignorant of the fact
that these children (ten in number) are left here on the
Reserve, during the winter, while the parents are away
hunting. They send in when they can, meat etc., but
some are hunting at a distance, and only come in at Amas
time. Then again, four of the children are orphans, with
no one to provide for them. Now my wife has been obliged
to increase the ration, and is now issuing 5 lbs daily,
including Saturday and Sundays (5 lbs for ten children)
What I ask is that the Department increase the rations,
and this coming winter forward a double supply of food for
use during winter 1921-1922, as the children situated as
they are here, require more than a mid-day meal.

MRS MAGGIE BEAR RECEIVES THE SUM OF TEN
dollars per month for doing same; she not only prepares
the noon meal, but provides, fish, rabbits, wood etc and
takes complete charge of those ten children out of school
hours. You can see that the sum of $10.00 is quite in-
adequate for the work she is performing. Will you kindly
put the matter before the Department re increase of salary
for her?

Another Matter:- The Bishop last year ad-
vised me, to hand the drugs and destitute supplies over to
Mr. Bear H.S.C.O., manager, ere leaving for England. He
distributed same last winter, but informs me that he has
not received payment for same (Oct. 1st, 1919- June 30th
1920.) Mrs Morris was obliged to get a few things locally
for school children and she trusts she has not infringed
the rules of the Department by so doing.

But for this woman, the school could not be
carried on during the winter months. Philip McKenzie has
kindly loaned his house and there Mrs. Bear and the child-
ren live. An improved Day School is needed here with
sleeping accommodation for about 10 children. As the build-
ing of a house for the children, Archdeacon Mahay has promi-
sed to take the matter up with the Department. This is
quiet Reserve during winter months with just the Storekeeper
School children, and ourselves around.

Trusting that you will give these matters
your attention. Thanking you in anticipation,

faithfully yours
(cgd.) C. Morris (Rev.)
Missionary in charge.

Indian Commissioner.
Ottawa, November 3, 1920.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 25th ultimo enclosing a communication from the Rev. C. Morris, missionary in charge of the Stanley Mission, Lac la Ronge, referring to certain matters relating to the school at that point.

In regard to the supplies for the mid-day meal I beg to say that supplies consisting of bacon, flour, tea, etc., for this purpose have already been forwarded and it will not be possible to increase the supply this season. The Department was not aware that a number of children are being boarded while their parents are away hunting. It is considered that the parents should provide meat and other supplies for the maintenance of their children over and above the amount provided by the mid-day meal. With reference to the building of a house for the accommodation of these children, I beg to say that there are no funds available for this purpose.

Regarding an increase in salary to Mrs. Maggie Bear for the preparation of the mid-day meal I beg to say that at present the sum of $10.00 per month is allowed her for this work, but, in view of the fact that her duties comprise more than the preparation of the mid-day meals, the Department will allow her an increase to the rate of $20.00 per month, as recommended by you, payable for the ten months the school is in operation each year, and properly certified vouchers should be forwarded from time to time covering her salary at that rate.

With reference to the dispensing at this point I beg to say in connection with this matter that Mr. Crombie, late Inspector of Indian Agencies, in a letter to the Department, No. 18-6, of March 4th, 1920, recommended that in future pay lists for the dispensers in the Isle a la Crosse Agency cover the period from September to September, and the Department in its reply of the 9th of March stated that it approved of his suggestion. No pay lists have been received for the salary of the dispensers in that agency covering the amount due from September 30th, 1919, and I have to request that you will be good enough to submit pay lists for the year ended September 30th, last, and you may include the name of Mr. Bear, who acted as dispenser at Stanley Mission during the winter, Mr. and Mrs. Morris were absent, namely, from October 1st, 1919, to June 30, 1920. Each of the dispensers is allowed $50.00 per annum for this work. As soon as these pay lists are received the amount of salary due the dispensers in this agency will be paid.

It is noted that Mrs. Morris, the teacher, purchased a few things locally for the school children. If she will forward an account with proper receipts attached covering the expenditure incurred by her, payment will be considered.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,

OTTAWA, Sept. 8th, 1921.

Right Reverend Sir,

A communication has been received from Mrs. Mabel Morris, the former teacher of the Stanley Indian Day School, in which she states that she has closed that school as her husband has been appointed missionary in charge of another district, and that she was leaving Stanley on the 20th of June last, to take up work on the Moose Lake Reserve, in The Pas Agency. Your Lordship is, no doubt, aware of this change having been made.

It will be necessary to secure another teacher for the Stanley school. However, in view of the fact that a number of the Indians are away with their families during the winter, and, owing to the difficulty in securing a teacher to take charge and the expense of transportation, it might be advisable to allow this school to remain closed until the Spring. The above is submitted for your consideration, but, if you think it advisable that the school should be continued, and you can obtain a teacher, the Department will consent to the school being reopened.

The name, qualifications and experience of any teacher nominated by you for the position should be submitted for the consideration of the Department.

I shall be pleased to have Your Lordship's views regarding the continuing of the school, and whether you can obtain a teacher or not.

I have the honour to be, Right Reverend Sir,

Your obedient servant,

On the 17th ult., accompanied by Sp. Const. Canada, with power canoe, I left on a police patrol to Stanley and Lac La Ronge, Sask. I arrived at Stanley the following night, staying there until the morning of the 21st ult., when I left for Lac La Ronge settlement where I arrived the same evening. The patrol had good travelling weather, but very low water was noted and two extra portages had to be made. Residents report the water the lowest they have ever seen it; slight frosts have already visited the district killing some garden vegetables and flowers. No. 3 Photographic Detachment of the R.C.A.Force (3 aeroplanes) on survey work were found engaged working out of the settlement, the patrol put up at La Ronge until the morning of the 27th ult., when a start was made for Pelican Narrows, where the patrol arrived back on the evening of the 9th ult.

At Stanley settlement I met four prospectors, and learned that others had visited the district during the summer, a number of the Indians were staying at the settlement, while others were camped nearby where the fishing was good, their health appeared to be good and no cases of destitution came to my notice, the amount of destitute supplies for this band has been increased this year. No serious crime came to my attention. I learned that Solomon Cook, Charles Cook and Phillip Charles, Indians, were contemplating trapping west of Lac Du Brochet and intended leaving their families at the settlement all winter. Solomon Cook did so last winter and did not arrange for sufficient upkeep for his family. I took this matter up with the men and told them they had to take their families with them or else arrange for their upkeep during the winter. I visited the day school and learned from Miss B. Allcock-teacher, that with one exception, the attendance had been satisfactory during the past summer months, the exception was Samuel Charles, age 13, son of Osidian Charles, this boy will not attend school regularly, out of 40 teaching days he has only attended on 14 days, and last year out of 69 teaching days he only attended 11 days. I spoke to this boy and also his parents. I would respectfully suggest that perhaps the Dept. of Indian Affairs would arrange to have this boy sent to an Indian industrial school, this as an example to others. I did not take any action against the parents as there is no Justice of the Peace at Stanley.

Indians of this settlement who trapped near Hatchet Lake (Hollaston Lake on maps) last winter, did not have a very successful fur hunt; it is reported that there were too many trappers in that district.

At Lac La Ronge I investigated a drowning accident in which Simon Morasty and Solomon Hallett-Indians, lost their lives, and a shooting accident which proved fatal to Alfred Rat-Indian. I have
submitted separate reports regarding these. A large number of prospectors have visited this district during the summer, and aeroplanes are a common sight there. I did not hear of any case in which prospectors interfered with the Indians; a number of Indians have obtained work as guides, fighting bush fires and clearing the channel in the Montreal River; this work has proved a great help to them, and has enabled them to pass the summer comfortably.

Regarding the use of Indian medicine, mentioned in my report of Jan. 26th last, Miss O.J. Gibson, registered nurse at the school and mission, states that more Indians and half-breeds are now opposed to her for drugs and treatment; she has not heard of John Ross or Mrs. Irwin prescribing Indian medicine since last winter. I made what other enquiries I could regarding this matter, and believe the practice has now stopped. The girl Mary Charles—mentioned in my report of Jan. 26th—died two weeks after I visited her.

I heard rumours that a white trapper named Frank Russell, had run off a batch of brew, on an island a few miles from the settlement, towards the end of last June, as far as I could find out, no Indians were mixed up in it; Russell had left for his winter trapping grounds before the patrol reached the settlement, and I did not think it of any use to patrol to his trapping camp and to search it.

The supply of destitute rations for the Indians in the district has been increased; these rations are distributed by the Principal of the Indian Boarding School, who was away on holidays while the patrol was at the scene. The residents of the settlement were preparing for the winter commercial fishing season, and everything points to them passing a good winter.

I was away thirteen days on this patrol and covered 320 miles by canoe.

Dear Sir -

With reference to establishing ten months' schools at Stanley and Pelican Narrows, Saskatchewan, we understand that the Department's Agents have decided that the three months' schools are not a success./ Rev's E. Ahenakew and H.E. Hives have talked the matter over with the Indians at Stanley and they are ready to let children of school age stay at Stanley for the Winter while they themselves go trapping if suitable arrangements are made for the care of the children. When Mrs. Morris was in charge of this School up to the year 1921, a widow woman was allowed $10 per month by the Department to cook for these children and I believe they slept in one of the Indian houses. Will the Department be willing to make some arrangement of this kind for the care of the children? We expect to have no difficulty in finding a teacher when the time comes. We beg to recommend strongly that this school be carried on as a ten months' school instead of a Summer School. With regard to rations, the Department used to send up bacon, rice, tea &c., and the Indians helped with fish and moose-meat.

Re "Pelican Narrows" School, the Indians have decided that Sandy Narrows would be a better site for the School than Pelican Narrows. They would leave their children there during the Winter and provide fish and wild meat as at Stanley. They were disappointed at not having a School last Summer, but are pleased now at the thought of having a ten months' School.
There is no school building or teacher's residence at either Pelican or Sandy Narrows. When the Summer School was held, the Church building was used for a school and the teacher lived either in a tent or in an Indian house. New buildings would therefore be needed at Sandy Narrows and all school equipment and supplies. The Indians at this point have had very little chance of getting their children educated and we strongly urge that this new effort be undertaken. Rev. E. Ahenakew talked over this matter with Mr. Russell Ferrier in Ottawa in September and I believe he will give a favourable report on the matter. Another reason why Sandy Narrows seems to be the better site is that there is good soil there and the Indians have quite large potato gardens at that point and the fishing is better than at Pelican Narrows.

Hoping that this application will receive favourable consideration,

I am, Sir,

Yours faithfully,

W. E. J. Paul

Archdeacon.

I visited this school on July the 16th and found eleven boys and thirteen girls present. Mrs. Nunn, a properly qualified teacher was acting in a temporary capacity, pending the arrival of the regularly appointed teacher. The average attendance for July, up to the time of my visit, was twenty pupils.

A married man.
married man named Mr. T.M. Gilmore, has been appointed as teacher, and his arrival was daily expected when I was there. It is, I understand, the intention to keep this school open all the year round, and in order to do this, there are certain difficulties which will have to be met. It is impossible for the parents to reside at Stanley steadily, inasmuch as their sole source of livelihood is derived from hunting, fishing and trapping, and these occupations necessarily entail them being at widely scattered points. If they were to reside steadily at Stanley, they could not make a living. They appreciate this, and the members of the band and myself had a long talk over the question. They appear to be very anxious to have their children given an opportunity to acquire an education, and in particular a knowledge of the English language. Very few members of this band speak English. They stated that they had two houses available for the use of the children, and proposed that the girls be given one house and the boys the other, and that each house should be in charge of an Indian woman who would do the cooking for them and give them supervision. A man would remain to provide fish and fire-wood for them. They want to give this a trial and agreed to request the Department to expend sufficient from the funds of their band to provide flour, tea, sugar and lard. They will find the meat and fish. I would recommend that their request be given consideration so that a trial may be made of this plan, during the coming winter, as it would be difficult at this time of the year to get supplies in to them, I would suggest that if this plan receives favourable consideration that the teacher be authorized to purchase what is necessary locally. There

is a branch
is a branch of both the Hudson's Bay Company and Revillon Freres at this point, and they allow the Department 25% off their regular prices, but I think it would be worth while to ask Revillon Freres to apply the goods at the same price as the destitute supplies were delivered under contract.

I am attaching hereto the resolution signed by the Chief and Head Men and witnessed by myself.

School is held in a log building, which was intended to be a 1½ story building, but there is no upstairs. The Indians promised to replaster and put this building into proper repair for the winter months. They have no school furniture, but just a few rough benches and tables.

Part of the equipment asked for by the Indians was a team of horses and a bob-sleigh to enable them to haul wood for the school and bring in supplies from Isle a la Crosse. I would not advise sending a team in until we are assured that sufficient hay has been put up to feed them during the winter. I may say in this connection that the school is built on a point on the Churchill River and the wood has to be rafted in in the summer and hauled by dogs in the winter. In the event of horses being supplied, the teacher would have to be made responsible for their care.

The Indians appear to be really anxious to have this school kept open all year round, and I found them very willing to promise to do their share in making this possible.

The foregoing report is respectfully submitted,

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Dear Mr. Scott:

There has been some difficulty in keeping the children in school at the Day school of the Amos Charles Reserve at Stanley, as the children have to accompany their parents on the hunt, which is their only means of making a livelihood. With regard to the Indian boys and girls being left in charge of an Indian woman or man, I doubt very much whether this would be a satisfactory arrangement. I might, however, suggest that, if there were a large number of children, it would be wise to employ a white man and his wife to supervise these boys and girls. It is so late in the season that it would be practically impossible to complete arrangements for this plan, but I would ask that this matter be given consideration by the Department, so that it might be carried out in the manner which I suggested, probably next summer.

Your obedient servant,

Re Stanley Seasonal School.

Mr. Ahab Spence will finish his College course at the beginning of May, and the Bishop has asked me to nominate him as Teacher of above School for the coming season.

Last year the Department said the school should be kept open from June 1st. to Oct. 31st, but it seems impossible to do this, as the people all go away to distant trapping grounds in September. Do you think it would be possible to arrange for the school children to be looked after at Stanley while their parents were away as was done a few years ago?

Spence himself would rather spend the remainder of the year doing missionary work exclusively, but it will be easier for us to find the balance of his salary, if he receives a salary from the Department for some considerable portion of the year. And of course the children will make better progress if the school term lasts longer.

He plans to visit the trapping camps during the winter, and to stay a good many days in each camp, and perhaps in this way he could help the children to go on with their studies during the winter. I believe in this way he could earn the $475, (5 months @ $95 per month) which the Department offered last year. Would you be willing to recommend this suggestion to the Department?

Sir:

I beg to inform the Department that on September 8th I received a communication from Mr. F. M. Gilmour, whose services as teacher at the Stanley Day School, Ile a la Crosse Agency, terminated on September 2nd. Mr. Gilmour stated in his letter that he had left the school returns in the school register at Stanley and, as it would take some time to get them from there, he urged that his salary be paid at once. I replied informing him that on the same date his letter was received here a copy of the school returns for the period he mentioned came to hand as well and I therefore concluded that the original return must have gone forward to Ottawa direct from Stanley. Reverend Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 2nd instant, I may say that the monthly salary rate for the teacher of the Stanley School is $90.00. The information that we received indicated that you commenced duties on April 29; consequently, you were paid for 2 days in April, or 2/30 of 90 = $6.00 plus $90.00 for the month of May, making a total of $96.00.

By a recent Order-in-council we are required to deduct 5% from all salaries of employees in the Public Service appointed to temporary positions since September 1, 1939. This money is deposited and principal and interest is repaid when you give up duties as teacher of an Indian day school. Consequently, 5% was deducted from your $90.00 salary for the month of June and a cheque for $85.50 was sent you.

Referring to your letter quoted above, in which it is stated that the Department would pay for material bought and paid for by the Anglican Church to the extent of $250.00 for the purpose of erecting a school building at Stanley, I have the honor to enclose herewith accounts which I have received from Ven Archdeacon McKay, and which aggregate $250.00.

It will be observed that one of these accounts is for freighting material for the building from Lac La Ronge to Stanley. This one amounts to $44.10; a second amounting to $179.79 includes an item of $34.10 for labor in preparing material for building, and other items amounting to $69.00 for Rubberoid roofing, while the balance of the account is made up of provisions which no doubt were issued to pay or ration the men engaged upon the work. In explanation of this account, the Archdeacon states that the lumber and hardware was all supplied by the Lac La Ronge School and that it amounted to very much more than the sum shown in this account, but that he has shown only $26.11 as being the balance of the "Grant."

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 18th ultimo enclosing a copy of a letter from Mrs. Mabel Morris, teacher of the Stanley Day School, in which she asks that the remuneration should be increased to $500.00, the same as she was receiving at Ohemawewin, Le Pas Agency.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will allow Mrs. Morris a salary at the rate of $500.00 per annum for her services as teacher of this school and she will also be allowed $50.00 per annum for dispensing medicines. Kindly inform her accordingly.

It is noted that she states that she re-opened the school early in October. She should prepare and forward a return showing the number of days she taught during the December quarter, last, when a cheque for the amount of salary due her will be forwarded.

In reference to the last paragraph of your letter I beg to say that, as you suggest, the allowance of $10.00 a month for assistance in preparing the noon meal at this school will be discontinued. You will be good enough to inform the teacher accordingly and also that she should get the assistance of some of the older pupils in the preparation of the noon meal.

Dear Sir,

We have now returned to our Mission & I hope to open school in the course of a few weeks. Today the mail arrived & with it a cheque for teaching (March quarter 1919) & another bonus cheque for quarter ending Sep. 1919.

In your last letter you state that I have received the whole of the money which I paid the Indian woman for preparing mid-day meals. I believe there is $30 (thirty dollars) still owing me. The woman prepared meals from Oct 1st 1918 - July 31st 1919 making $100 in all.
I was paid in the first place $50, covering the first five months from Oct 1st 1918 - Feb 28th 1919. Then I next received $10 for month of June, & another, for same amount, for month of July. If the $30 was forwarded to me before crossing to England, I am sorry to trouble you, but I cannot remember receiving same, but if you have a cheque for that amount bearing my signature then I must be at fault.

Thanking you for an early reply.

Yours truly,
Mabel Morris.
Ottawa, August 9, 1920.

Sir,

The Department is in receipt of a letter from Mrs. Mabel Morris who has recently returned from England and intends to again take charge of the Stanley Indian Day School.

She claims that there is a balance due her of $30.00 in order to pay the Indian woman who prepared the mid-day meals from October 1, 1918 to July 1, 1919, a period of ten months.

The Department has made the following payments:
- Ck. No. 1219 sent on the 17th of September, 1919, for $10.00 in payment for the month of July, 1919.
- Ck. No. 968 for $10.00 sent on the 6th of August, 1919, for the month of June 1919, and ck. No. 947 for $50.00 sent on the first of August, 1919, payments for the months of February, March, April and May, 1919 and October, 1918.

From the above it would appear that no payments were made for the months of November and December, 1918, and January 1919. As the school was open during those months it is apparent that there is a balance due Mrs. Morris of $30.00 for preparing the midday meal, and I would request that you forward a voucher for this amount for the months stated above.

Your obedient servant

Assistant Deputy and Secretary

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Regina, Sask.

She thanks the Department for extra allowance granted her, the same, according to your instructions, to date from Nov. 1st. Will you kindly enquire into the matter for me?

Extract from letter to Archdeacon Paul from the Rev. H.E. Hives, January 1932.

.... The school has proven a great success owing to the work of preparation and continuation done by the chief. The people all responded to his appeal for workers to attend to the various tasks and the W.A. provided the food for those who worked. The two houses belonging to the chief are the ones being used for the children as the grant promised by the Indian Department could not come in time to be fitted up for the fall. Other arrangements will have to be made another year as the chief says he cannot always give his house as he might have occasion to need it himself.

Mr. Gilmore told me that after having seen you he was of the impression that a new school was to be built this coming summer. If this is the case the material in the old school could be used to build the two houses necessary to accommodate the children. In any case whether the present school is refashioned or other houses built for the children's use the following hardware will be necessary:

- 30 lbs 4" nails
- 25 lbs 1½" nails
- 30 lbs 2½" nails
- 2 door locks
- 2 sets door hinges
- 25 lengths stove pipe 6"
- 4 elbows 6"
- 2 rolls wire for pipes
- 2 dampers for pipes 6"

This material should be sent this winter so that it can be used during the summer. The necessary doors and windows and shingles should be ordered also. Some grant for lumber should be included which could be secured from the mill at Lac la Ronge. The money for all this expense was voted last summer by the Indians to be taken from the band funds. The Inspector, Mr. Muirison, would have the record of this. This is for the children's houses and not for any school building which might be contemplated.

Regarding Mr. Gilmore he has done very good work in the school and is very much liked by both the children and the people.
Dear sir -

When I saw you last September you told me that you thought the Department would build a new Class-room for the Stanley School next Summer. Would it be possible for the material for this building to be sent up during the present Winter? The freighting of heavy material is almost impossible in Summer when travel is only by canoe, but teams and sleighs go up in Winter. If you contemplate a lumber building, the dimension lumber at any rate could be obtained from the Lac la Ronge School mill. But a good log building with hewn logs with lime and sand plaster between the logs would, I think, meet the requirements. I enclose an extract from a letter to me from the Rev. H.E. Hives, the Missionary in charge of that district, mentioning the fact that the Band have voted money from their Fund to erect two houses, one for boys and one for girls, for the accommodation of the children during the Winter when their parents are away trapping, and giving a list of hardware needed for these houses. Inspector Muirson is acquainted with the whole situation and would, I am sure, give you whatever information you require. I would like to suggest that the Department supply the necessary hardware, doors, windows, shingles, stoves &c., and the Indians at Stanley would cut and hew the logs gratis if rations could be given them while working, both for Class-room and children's houses.

Mr. Gilmore, the Teacher, was out for a short time during the Christmas holidays. He appears to be doing very good work and the children are getting on well. Mr. Hives
carried out the erection of a new Mission house last Summer with only local help. Mr. Gilmore is living in it this Winter and finds it comfortable. I think therefore, that Mr. Hives' list of material needed could be relied on, but he is estimating for the children's houses, not the Class-room.

I know that the estimates are not passed till April, but I hope it will be possible to make arrangements for the necessary material to be sent to Stanley during the Winter.

Dear Mr. Morrison,

I beg to submit the following report on the schools which I inspected during the time I was Paying Officer for the Ile a la Crosse Agency.

STANLEY DAY SCHOOL:

I visited this school on July 15th and found 29 pupils present with Mr. T.M. Gilmore as teacher. The pupils appeared clean, healthy and well clothed.

In taking the classes in their various subjects I noticed some of the pupils were much further advanced than the majority, in spite of there being little or no difference in their ages. In questioning Mr. Gilmore regarding this he informed me the backward pupils were those who attended school during the summer months only. He also advised me that owing to the fact that these children attended school for three or four months, and then lived with their people during the balance of the year, resulted in them forgetting what they had learned at school.

In view of this it would appear to be a wasted effort in trying to teach these children under those conditions. However I found the children who had attended their classes during the winter months well advanced in their studies. These appeared keen and interested in their work, and all seemed anxious to return to their school this winter.

The Chief and members of this band are very anxious to keep this school open during the yearly school term and have voted the sum of $600.00 to be taken from band funds for that purpose. Dispensation of same as follows:

- $50.00 a year for housing, cooking & washing for girl pupils.
- $50.00 a year for " " " " " " boy "
- $50.00 a year for labor to supply fuel and fish for above
- $200.00 a year for food supplies from Revillon Freres Trading Co., Stanley.

$250.00 to ship in the following: 5 sacks flour, 100 lbs. pot barley, 100 lbs rolled oats, 50 lbs sugar, 25 lbs tea, 36 lbs lard and 200 candles.

These people advised me that if they could be assured this school was to be kept open the year round they would guarantee to increase the yearly average daily attendance from 24.01 to 45. In doing so the provider of each family would be able to give more time to his hunting and trap lines during the winter months.

I am attaching hereto the resolution, signed by the Chief and Head man which was witnessed by me, and would recommend it be given favorable consideration.

The foregoing report is respectfully submitted.

S.H. Simpson.

Sir:

I beg to forward a report on the schools included in the Isle a la Crosse Agency submitted by the Paying Officer for this year, Mr. S.H. Simpson.

STANLEY DAY SCHOOL.

The report in connection with this day school is not encouraging in view of the living conditions of the people. As these people derive their living by hunting and trapping, it is absolutely impossible for them to reside continuously at Stanley. Their means of livelihood takes them considerable distances from that point and it is obvious that unless residential facilities are provided for the school children to enable them to remain at Stanley all the year round, we cannot expect a regular and satisfactory attendance. It will be noted on Page 8 of the report the Paying Officer states that the Chief and members of this band are anxious to keep the school open during the term and have voted the sum of $600.00 to be taken from their band funds for that purpose. I question the advisability of doing this. The funds of that band are very limited and after all the granting of this money would only be a temporary expedient, as, if the funds are to be used from year to year for this purpose, they would soon become depleted and we would be confronted with the same situation as exists at present. In view of the resolutions having been passed, I am submitting them herewith.

W. Murison.
Inspector.

The funds at the disposal of the department for Indian education are so limited that it will not be possible for the department to authorize any expenditure in caring for the children while their parents are away on their trap lines. I will be glad if you will so inform the Chief and Councillors". I may inform you also that I notified the Venerable Archdeacon Paul, of Prince Albert, regarding the department's decision with reference to this matter, but notwithstanding this warning apparently the Chief and Councillors took the matter in their own hands and made arrangements for the care of the children. In view of the circumstances, I feel that the Indians responsible for this action should be called upon to pay for the services rendered.

Your obedient servant,

W. Murison,
Inspector,

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge your letter of the 25th ultimo reporting on the petition received from the Indians of Amos Charles Band, asking that payment be made for the services of persons looking after the children while the parents were absent trapping.

Official letter of the 7th of October 1932 definitely stated that provision could not be made for these Indian children during the winter and if the members of the Band have gone ahead in the face of these explicit instructions, the responsibility of making payment rests entirely with them. The Department must refuse to use the limited funds at the credit of this Band for the needless expenditure incurred contrary to the instructions from the Department and yourself.

I may inform you that on the recommendation of Mr. Weir, Indian Agent, the Department has approved of keeping the Stanley Day School open during the winter but this does not include providing food for them during the winter season.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of March 30th, file 132-4-1, in regard to keeping the Stanley Indian Day School open for a period of ten months; I went into this matter with the Indians and the widows of the Band agreed to stay in the village and look after the children while school is in progress. I feel sure that they would give the children good care.

At the present time there are twenty-eight children attending this school but this number would likely be reduced in the winter. I estimate that there would be approximately twenty children attending the school during the winter months. The parents of most of the children, that is the Hunting Indians, have agreed to leave their children at the village to attend the school.

I am enclosing a requisition, form 37, for the rations that I believe will be necessary for these children. The following supplies should be shipped in as soon as possible by the M & C Aviation Co. in order to keep the children until the balance of the groceries arrive by winter freight:

- 100 lbs lard
- 100 lbs sugar
- 100 lbs oatmeal
- 1 case prunes
- 48 lbs syrup

The Indians of the Band have agreed to supply the fish and potatoes that are necessary.

The school is now open for the usual 6-month period, and I would suggest that it be kept open for an additional 10 months, or until June 30th, 1939. After this year the school would only be open for the usual term. It is necessary to do this owing to the fact that the Indians go north to the trap lines and must leave their children at the village.

Hon. Sir,

Mr. Keith, Esq., the Indian agent for this District, has notified us that it is the intention of the Department to close the school on this Reserve. Having had eighteen years of missionary experience, will you allow me to say that a school at a mission station is a most valuable handmaid not only in the spiritual work, but also in helping to educate the rising generation with a view to usefulness in the Dominion. I was engaged, in conjunction with my wife, in educational work at York Factory, thirteen years, 1879-92. Several of our late scholars are now employed in good positions in Winnipeg & elsewhere. Without the advantages they doubtless would have followed the hunter's life, which in the present day is extremely precarious. Now a few have succumbed to starvation. I am sorry to say that the attendance has not been as good as we could have desired; but now that the Indians have heard of the possibility of closing the school they are greatly disturbed and promise to encourage the work in the future.

I ought add that, in the stronghold of heathenism in the district, the Indians do not take kindly to the blessings of civilization; but by inculcating Christian principles into the children I might be the means of elevating the entire band.

As Your Lordship is aware the improvement of Indian day school conditions has been for sometime receiving consideration and already marked improvement is noticeable in many instances. Some months ago particular attention was paid to the schools in the southern part of the North Saskatchewan Inspectorate, and, with a view to extending the work, the situation as existing on the more northern reserves has been looked into and reported upon, and the Department now wishes to try to effect an improvement at the Ahtahkakoop and Sturgeon Lake Schools.

RESERVE 106A.

On Reserve 106A there are 8 children of school age. Two of these, as indicated above, have been in attendance here; but the Indians who have kept them find themselves unable to keep them permanently; and at any rate such young children should not be sent away from home to live with other Indians, except under very exceptional conditions.

I have little doubt that if the residence accommodation in connection with this school could be utilized, the parents of all these eight children would gladly send them to board at the school during the week, at least from Monday to Friday. This would necessitate some further equipment of the residence, and furnishing Mrs. Godfrey, a good reliable woman, to act as matron or at least as help. However, this would probably be the best solution of the problem of education for Reserve 106A, where it is not likely it will ever be found advisable to establish a school.

Dear Mr. Foran:

I have your letter of the 25th instant, regarding the salary which is paid Mr. Henry W. Shaw, teacher of the Sturgeon Lake Indian Day School in the Carlton Agency.

Mr. Shaw has been teaching in Indian schools for a period of fifteen years. He was transferred as teacher to the Sturgeon Lake school from the school on the James Smith's Reserve on January 1, 1918. His salary while at the James Smith's school was $500 per annum, and he was transferred to Sturgeon Lake at the same salary, which he has continued to receive up to the present time. He is also provided with a residence. His wife performs duties as field matron on the Reserve. In addition to salary, he has been allowed bonus at the rate of $150 per annum from April 1, 1919. He has a First Grade State of Iowa Certificate. The Sturgeon Lake Indian Day School is conducted under the auspices of the Church of England, and he was nominated for the position of teacher by the Bishop of Saskatchewan, and his transfer from the James Smith's school to the Sturgeon Lake school was also made at the request of the Bishop.

I may say that no promise was made by this Department to grant Mr. Shaw an increase of $50 per year in his salary until such time as he would receive $900 per year. We do not give annual increases to teachers in Indian schools. When increases are granted, such are made on the recommendation of the Indian Agent or the School Inspector and in consideration of the work the teacher is performing.

We will take up with our Indian Agent the question of granting Mr. Shaw an increase in salary for the coming school year, beginning September 1st, next.

Yours very truly,

Mr. Murison's report on Day Schools, Carlton Agency.

Dear Mr. Graham,

I beg to submit the following report of a visit which I made to the four Day Schools operating in the Carlton Agency.

STURGEON LAKE DAY SCHOOL.

I visited this school on January 11th, and found only two children in attendance. There was an epidemic of La Grippe on this reserve and this school was closed on that account before I left the reserve. There are two centres of population on this reserve. The school is situated at the west end. There are eleven pupils enrolled which is all the children of school age residing within a reasonable distance of the school. The children of school age whose parents reside at the east end of the reserve are attending the residential schools at La-la-Ronge, Duck Lake and Onion Lake.

The school room has been repaired since my last visit one year ago. The windows on the north-west side have been closed and light now comes in from four windows on the south-west side of the room. The building is very comfortable. The room is 18' x 26' with a 12' ceiling. The exterior has been white washed and presents a neat appearance.

Mr. H.W. Shaw has been teacher here for many years, and is doing good work. His influence is good on the reserve. He works in harmony with the Department officials and the Principals of the residential schools. The Teacher's residence is a large well built frame building, and it is in good condition, it has been repainted and presents a good appearance. The furnace had burnt out beyond repair. This was reported at once to you and action taken to replace it.
Sir:-

I am enclosing herewith a report on the various schools in the Carlton Agency, which were visited by Mr. Inspector Murison.

With regard to the Sturgeon Lake Day School, there is nothing that requires particular attention, further than to mention the fact that the furnace in the teacher's residence which is reported as having burnt out beyond repair is being replaced at the present time.

There is nothing requiring attention in connection with the Day School on the Sioux Reserve.

The Big River Day School does not amount to much, and I doubt whether it would pay the Department to build a new school. My own opinion is that the time is coming when there will be a boarding school in the north to take care of the children on all these reserves.

With reference to the Inspector's remarks regarding Mr. Hutchinson, teacher at the Sandy Lake School, the Department are well aware of the situation at that point, and know all about Mr. Hutchinson. Memorandum - Concerning the Services of the Rev. E. V. Bird,
At present Teacher of the James Smith Indian Day School.

Rev. Mr. Bird was first employed by the Department at the Red Pheasant Indian Day School. He served there for 3 years, 1920-23, with considerable success. He applied for the principalship of the Mackay Indian Residential School and was given a fair trial there, somewhat against the advice of departmental officers. He was relieved of his duties in 1927, and Bishop Lloyd, when nominating him for the James Smith Indian Day School, stated that he had not been a success in the residential institution "as expected" (this file) (The appointment, of course, had been made by the M. S. O.). The trouble which led to his removal from the Mackay School was in connection with corporal punishment. Both the Church and the Department investigated, and the Church, on its own initiative, relieved him of his post. (128-1-1).

From 1927, Mr. and Mrs. Bird were at the James Smith Indian Day School (Fort a la Corne North). In October, 1930, the Church notified the Department that Mrs. Burbridge, teacher of the south end of the reserve, was leaving. A month later, Mrs. Burbridge put up a fight against her retirement and complained of the activities of the Rev. Mr. Bird. (109-9-1). Mr. Bird retaliated in January, 1931, by interesting the Honourable Mr. Weir in his behalf. Further, Mr. Bird wrote the Superintendent General, complaining of Indian Agent Schmidt (D. M.'s Private File 329) and she wrote the Department, protesting about the procedure in calling the medical officer to the reserve (9-109). In February, the Chief of the Band and the President of the Canadian Legion at Kinistino protested concerning Mrs. Burbridge's dismissal and complained about Mr. Bird. In March, Archdeacon Paul investigated conditions and found the reserve rather divided in its allegiance between the two workers (109-9-1). Mrs. Burbridge left in April, 1931.

In October, 1931, the Superintendent General asked the Department to remove Mr. Bird from the James Smith Indian Day School and arrangements have been made for him to leave in June, 1932. Bishop Hallam has had an interview with the Superintendent General and it was agreed that he would be transferred to the Sturgeon Lake Indian Day School.

The salary allowed her will be at the rate of $95 per teaching month, less 10 percent for the current fiscal year. The holiday period at the Stanley School was taken during the months of April and May, last, and it is presumed that this school has been in operation under Mr. Gilmore's charge during the months of July and August. Miss Merritt should take up duties at Stanley on September 1st, next. I shall be pleased if Your Lordship will inform the Department of Miss Merritt's Christian name, as this is necessary for our records.

I shall be pleased if Your Lordship will inform both the above named teachers of the approval granted for their appointment. The Department is informing the local Indian Agents of the above appointments, and requesting that they give these teachers every assistance they can in their work.

I have the honour to be,

Right Reverend Sir,

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

Re: H.W.Shaw - Our File 45686-PLS

We have your favor of recent date with enclosure of cheque for $125.00 on behalf of H.W. Shaw. For some time past you have sent cheques directed to ourselves under an assignment Mr. Shaw executed to us in security of certain claims. These claims have all been satisfied and we now authorize you to pay all monies, in future, to Mr. Shaw direct. His address is "Sturgeon Valley, Sask."

Yours truly,

LOUGHEED BENNETT & COMPANY

OTTAWA, September 22nd, 1922.

Sir -

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 11th instant, enclosing a requisition from the teacher of the Sturgeon Lake Indian Day School for certain supplies for the school and teacher's residence.

In reply I beg to say that you may purchase and have delivered to the teacher the following supplies: - 12 yards table calicoth, 1 large tea kettle, 1 large coffee pot, 1 large vegetable kettle, 12 knives and forks (cheap), 12 granite cups, 3 granite pans, 2 brooms, 2 galvanized water pails, 1 covered chamber pan, 24 tea spoons (cheap), 1 axe, 2 granite wash basins, 1 well bucket, 36 feet rope for well, 5 combs, 1 stew pan and 1 butcher knife.

Before purchasing the above articles, it will be necessary to obtain competitive prices, and the purchase should be made from the firm quoting the lowest price. While serviceable articles should be obtained, they should be as inexpensive as possible.

The teacher also requests that repairs be made to the furnace. You may have new grates and a new damper installed. The cold air pipes should also be soldered. No unnecessary expense should be incurred in placing the furnace in a good state of repair.

The teacher also requests that authority be given to employ labour to dig privy pits. If you consider that this work should be carried out, you may arrange to have it done.

When the above authorized articles have been purchased, and the repairs carried out, you should furnish properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred. A memo. should accompany the vouchers showing the names of the firms asked to quote a price and the prices quoted.

You will be good enough to give the matter of these purchases, and the repairs to the furnace, your prompt attention, and have the supplies delivered and the furnace repaired at an early date.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Indian Agent,

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 24th instant, regarding the desks required for the use of the Sturgeon Lake Indian Day School. We note that, owing to the condition of the desks at present in use, it is necessary to purchase new ones, as requested by the teacher.

The Department will, therefore, approve of the purchase of 12 single desks of the sizes required. You should consult the teacher as to the sizes and you may arrange for the purchase and delivery. It will be necessary, however, to obtain competitive prices, before buying; and you should ask the following firms to quote a price for the delivery of the desks, f. o. b. the nearest railway station to the school, viz.:

Please make the purchase from the firm quoting the lowest price, and forward properly certified vouchers covering the expenditure incurred, accompanied by a memo, showing the names of the firms asked to quote and the prices quoted. Extract from Report of Inspector Murison on the Sturgeon Lake Indian Day School.

I visited this school on January 27th, 1926.

The school building is of logs on a stone foundation; it is rough cast on the outside and sealed with lumber on the inside. The class room is 18 x 26 and the ceiling is 12 feet high. The teacher reports that it is very easily heated, and he has no trouble in keeping it comfortable even in the coldest of weather notwithstanding the fact that there are no storm windows. The room is lighted by four windows, two on each side, each having four lights with glass 15" x 30". This is an old size and hard to replace. To conform with the public school standards the two windows might be taken from one side of the building and placed on the other so as to bring the light in over the left shoulder, but except from this the building is quite suitable in my opinion and will serve the purpose satisfactorily for some time yet. I note that one panel was broken out of the door and think it would be better to supply a new door, as they aren't very expensive, rather than attempt to repair it.

With further reference to the windows I may say that the old sash is in a decayed condition and the window sash will have to be replaced very shortly. It would be advisable when replacing these windows to obtain them of a standard size.

The teacher's dwelling is a large two storey building with a basement heated by a hot air furnace. This building has not been repainted since it was built in 1911. It was originally white with green trimmings, and the paint has stood remarkably well. It should, however, now be repainted.

Commissioner Graham forwarded the above under cover of his letter of February 19, 1926, and states:

"The first school dealt with is Sturgeon Lake. Certain repairs are required at this school such as replacing the sash, supplying a new door, etc. It seems to me that this could be done for less than $50.00 and if money is available for this I will have the work done at once. If there is money available for painting the teacher's residence I could buy the paint now and have it put on after the 31st of March."

STURGEON LAKE DAY SCHOOL.

I visited this school on November 25th, and found 7 boys and 9 girls in attendance, out of an enrolment of 20. The average attendance for the month was 15, which is very good for cold weather. Of the children enrolled, 10 are under 7 years, 7 are 12 years and under, and 3 over 12. The teacher at this school co-operates in influencing the parents to send the older children to the boarding school. He now has a lot of very young children, but they are bright and very interesting. I found them clean and warmly clad. They speak up well and I found conditions I think more satisfactory than I have ever found them at this school. Mr. Henry Shaw continues as teacher at this point. He has had many years experience teaching Indian day schools.

The building I found clean and comfortable. The teacher has no desk and I would recommend that one be supplied. I noted that the heating stove is pretty well burnt out and it should be replaced with a new one.

The teacher's residence has been newly painted and the interior partly re-decorated. There is material on hand to finish this work. It was noted that the kitchen floor, 10 x 16, is badly worn and should be replaced.
Dear Mr. Scott:

I am enclosing herewith a report on the five Day schools in the Carlton Agency.

The average attendance at the Sturgeon Lake Day School is not bad, considering the conditions under which the Indians are living. This is undoubtedly the best school of the lot. You will note that the teacher has no desk. It might be a good idea to send one from Eaton's as it would cost very little. There is nothing in the Estimates to provide for a floor for the teacher's residence. This, however, would not cost more than $25.00. The heating stove in the building should be replaced without delay. This will cost about $35.00.

W. M. Graham,

STURGEON LAKE DAY SCHOOL.

I visited this school on the 8th of March. It was a very stormy day and only 2 girls and 1 boy were present out of an enrolment of 12 boys and 5 girls. This school is under the auspices of the Anglican Church. Rev. F. T. Fife had been in charge as teacher for three weeks previous to my visit. His wife has been taken on as assistant teacher. The average attendance for January and February at this school was about 6. These were very cold months and the children have, in some instances, a long way to come to the school. At one time drivers were provided in connection with this school, and owing to the fact that there are two centres of population, one at the east and one at the west end of the reserve, it does not seem probable that the average attendance will be satisfactory.

STURGEON LAKE INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

This school is a log building, but I found it clean and nicely decorated. Mr. F. J. Fife is the teacher in charge, and he appeared greatly interested in his work.

The children were away before I arrived, but the register showed 20 on the roll. The children come from a distance of half a mile to four miles, and I noticed the average attendance for September ranged around 15. A number of children on the east side of the reserve are too far away to attend.

A noon lunch is served, and this is prepared by Mrs. Fife, who acts as Field Matron. Soup and biscuits make up the main portion of the meal.

Sir,

I received yours of November 6th, advising me that there will be no more help allowed for the preparing of the mid-day meal for the school children after this year. The Department surely cannot realize the amount of work this means. I was asked last March to continue my work of dispensing drugs and caring for the sick on this reserve, without salary, and I have done this as faithfully as when I drew my salary, and have saved the Indian Department some big hospital bills, for which I would refer you to Doctor Boucher of Deben.

It is asking a great deal to expect any one person to continue all this besides being tied to the kitchen five whole mornings out of each week for the preparing and serving up of a hot nourishing meal for thirty odd children. This meal is most necessary as some of these children walk a distance of five miles to attend school, and for most of them it is the only nourishing meal they get during the week.

I would ask that this matter be reconsidered.

Yours truly,

(Sgd) C.E. Goodman.

Inspector's Report on Indian Day Schools,
Carlton Agency - Saskatchewan

Sir:-

I beg to submit the following report on the Day Schools in the Carlton Agency which I visited during the month of February.

Sturgeon Lake Day School

I visited this Day school on the 16th instant, Saturday, and consequently the children were not in attendance. I noted the condition of the buildings. The school building was built many years ago of spruce logs and has served its purpose. This building, according to information given me, was built over fifty years ago at the east end of the Reserve and was later moved to its present location.

The teacher's residence is a large frame building, heated with a hot air furnace. This building was originally intended as a semi-residential school, the rear wing being added so that outlying pupils could be accommodated with sleeping quarters from Monday until Friday night. It has however not been used for this purpose and this addition is not required by the teacher. I examined the wing and found that by making some alterations a classroom, 16' x 28', could be provided as well as cloakrooms. This could be done, I am satisfied, at very little cost and would make it unnecessary to provide a separate school building. The ceilings downstairs in the part occupied as a residence by the teacher require replastering. There are two basements under the building, one under the wing mentioned and the other under the portion occupied by -

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
portion occupied by the teacher. In the event of remodeling this wing for classroom purposes, I would suggest that a small pipeless furnace be placed in the basement for heating the wing.

I noticed that the outside toilets were in bad condition and should be replaced with new structures.

The premises appeared to be fairly neat and tidy.

There were 17 pupils enrolled, 11 girls and 6 boys, and the average attendance for February was 10.13. For the December quarter the percentage of attendance was 84.42. The highest percentage of attendance was in November 87.50.

The present teacher, Mr. T. E. Macdonald, is a young married man. He holds a second class Saskatchewan certificate. His wife is also a qualified teacher. Mr. Macdonald impressed me as being energetic and capable. I am looking for conditions to improve under his management, as I believe he is the best qualified teacher we have had at this school for many years.

I saw the children in their homes and was favorably impressed by their cleanly appearance. I may say that the Indians of the Sturgeon Lake Reserve generally keep their homes and persons in a clean condition. This particularly applies to the families in close proximity to the school from which the pupilage is obtained.

W. Morrison

Dear Sir:-

On my last visit to the Sturgeon Lake Reserve, before going North, I found about 30 windows had been broken in the Indian Day School, and residence of the teacher. I found that the young children of the Reserve had done this damage and advised the parents that they would have to replace this glass.

The Indians have now taken up this matter with me and wish to pay for the glass from their Band Funds, the parents of the children putting the windows in free of charge. They also assure us that there will not be a repetition of this occurrence.

If the Department will grant this request, I will forward a resolution from this Band with the bill of glass.

Yours truly,

R. S. Davis,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Can.
Leask, Sask.
Sept. 18th. 1937.

Dear Sir:

On the Sturgeon Lake Reserve we have about seventeen children who live from eight to three and one half miles from the school. Most of these people want to send their children to Boarding Schools but in my opinion it would be far more economical to have a bus take these children to the Day school in the morning and return them home at night. This would be an easy matter as the road passes near most of these homes.

The cost, to hire a man and team to do this work, at the present time would be about forty dollars ($40.00) per month and an outlay of about fifty dollars ($50.00) for a caboose.

Would you kindly take this matter up with the Dept. and see if there is anything that can be done in this matter. In the meantime I am withholding sending these children to the Boarding school.

Yours truly,

R. S. Davis,
Indian Agent.

Dr. Thos. Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Regina, Sask.
Dear Sir;-

Yours truly,

Thos. Robertson,

The Department is in receipt of your letter of September 30th, enclosing letter received from Indian Agent Davis with reference to transporting children to the Sturgeon Lake Indian Day School.

It is noted that there are seventeen children who live from 3½ to 5 miles from the school and that the Agent considers these could be taken to school each morning and returned in the evening.

You may authorize Indian Agent Davis to arrange for the transporting of these children at a cost of $40.00 a month, plus an outlay of approximately $50.00 for a caboose.

Dear Sir:-

Re - Your Letter Dec. 7th., No. 107-9-5

We are returning herewith the corrected voucher for the wages due Mr. Brant of Sturgeon Valley for driving the School bus for part of November. We regret the error in first computing the rate as set out in our previous voucher.

The reason that we have vouchered for only part of November for Mr. Brant is because he was replaced on Nov. 29th by an Indian, Wm. Kingfisher, of the Sturgeon Lake Reserve. The voucher for Wm. Kingfisher's wages at the end of December will contain the two days of November.

The reason for the change was that Mr. Brant did not possess a team of horses, having used his car up to the 27th., when the roads became impassable for this vehicle. And further we thought that it would be advisable to give this Indian an opportunity to earn some money to support his family. At the time the bus was first started the Indians were all busy and it was difficult to get a good man but since the winter has set in there was a better opportunity to get a capable Indian for this position.

We trust that the above will be meet with your approval.

Dear Sir:

In regard to the transportation of the children to the Sturgeon Lake Indian Day School, your letter No. 107-9-5 of Oct. 8th., I regret very much that I overlooked sending a report on the number of children using this bus up to the Christmas Holidays but I have been very busy.

In the month of October and November an average of five children each day were using the bus. This average was small on account of the epidemic of Typhoid Fever on the Reserve. In the month of December the average was ten children per day. Most of these children come from the far end of the Reserve, which is about eight miles away.

I have kept the bus running through the month of January, though after looking up my authority, I realize that I should not have done this without first receiving your authority. The bus is still running and I wish you would advise me whether it should continue.

Yours truly,

Indian Agent.

Ottawa,

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 2nd instant with reference to the transportation of the children to the Sturgeon Lake Indian Day School. When this matter was first brought to our attention it was stated approximately 17 children would take advantage of the bus. However, it is noted from your letter that there were only 5 during the months of October and November and 10 during the month of December. Provided the number using the bus does not go much below 10 the Department is prepared to continue the transportation of the children until the end of June. At that time you should forward a statement showing the average number of children transported each month during the academic year 1937-38 and when this information is received the Department will be in a position to decide if this service should be provided during the next academic year.
