Dear Sir:

It appears from requisition dated the 6th instant from the teacher of the Sturgeon Lake Indian Day School that she wishes to raise chickens at the school. In forwarding this requisition you made no comment and before approving the teacher's request the Department would appreciate receipt of a recommendation from you. While it would like to encourage Indians to raise chickens at the same time it would want to be assured that if this project was started at the Sturgeon Lake Day School it would be conducted for the benefit of the pupils and it would further require definite assurance that you feel that such action would be beneficial to all parties concerned.

In the event of the teacher leaving for summer holidays who would be in charge of the chickens?

On the requisition the teacher also requests a water pump. Please let me know the approximate cost of this and if you consider it necessary.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,

Leask, Sask.,
June 4th, 1938.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of May 27th, file 107-9-5, in regard to the requisition for chickens for the Sturgeon Lake Indian Day School; I believe that the raising of chickens at any school would be a wonderful thing.

However, at this point, the teacher employed by the Department is a young girl, Miss Dessie O Brant. Her father, mother, brother and sister live with her. Her father is employed by the Church as Missionary and is the one who would be looking after the chickens.

Mr. Brant would like to take over the school duties from his daughter and I believe that Arch. Deacon Paul will be taking this matter up with you later. In this event the chickens would be well looked after, but if Miss Brant continued as the teacher she might get married or leave the position, and it would then be necessary for the family to move and the next teacher appointed might not be in favour of the experiment.

I feel quite sure, if Mr. Brant was the teacher, that the chickens would be used for the right purpose and he would not leave the Reserve for very long in the summer holidays.

I would recommend that the matter be left in abeyance until next year until the question of the Teacher is definitely settled.

Yours truly,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Can.

Dear Sir:

In regard to your letter of November 4th, file 107-9-5 with reference to the need of desks at the Sturgeon Lake Indian Day School, I may say that I advised the teacher at that time of the contents of your letter of January 18th 1939, file 107-9-4, in which you stated that no funds were available at that time for desks and to submit a requisition in April. As April was near the end of the term I considered that it would be better to wait for the end of the term and requisition for new desks for the new term; Miss Brant, the teacher at that time was so informed.

However, there was a change of teachers and the requisition was not submitted until November. On November 6th I forwarded a requisition for 10 desks for this school for children 12 years old. The proper size, according to your letter, would be size 3, ages 10 to 12.

I am very sorry that the Department has been criticized by Inspector Tomlinson but I would like to point out that it not altogether my fault as, unfortunately, I have one of the largest Agencies in the Province and have less help than some of the smaller Agencies and it is impossible for me to keep my work up to date.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing herewith copy of a memorandum received by this Branch from W. M. Bailey, Departmental Purchasing Agent. The subject matter of this memorandum, you will note, is self-explanatory.

I may state that the Multi Use Cream to which the Purchasing Agent refers costs $6.45 per gallon. He is of the opinion that first grade paint, equally if not more serviceable, might have been secured at $3.00 to $3.50 per gallon.

I am not, as you are no doubt aware, responsible either for the employment, suspension or dismissal of Indian gents. I do feel, however, that I should in fairness to myself point out to you that I have been called upon altogether too frequently during the last few months either to explain or justify or defend the actions of Indian Agent Davis. If this man is over-worked, he should be supplied with additional help; if the agency is too large, ways and means should be considered of reducing it; or if he is dissatisfied with conditions in the Carlton agency, consideration should be given to his removal to another agency. In view of the number of complaints that have reached me with respect to his work, I have no alternative other than to summarize these complaints and to send them on to the higher officials for their consideration and for whatever action they may deem necessary, in view of all the circumstances.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I wish to bring to your attention that I have just had a letter from Mr. Raymond G. Robinson, teacher of the Sturgeon Lake Indian Day School at Sturgeon Lake, in the Carlton Agency, and in this letter he points out that the boys and girls who are attending the school devoted much time and labour on the school garden and their efforts were not in vain as the school have a good supply of potatoes, onions, cabbages, carrots, and turnips in the basement. I know this to be true because I saw their garden and they had a fine crop.

Mr. Robinson further mentions what a Godsend it would be to the children if they could have some meat to put in with their stew of vegetables. He states the $50.00 they are allowed for noon-day lunches is spent on the following: flour, cocoa, rice, beans, lard, yeast cakes, pepper, salt, macaroni, etc., therefore they have nothing with which to buy meat.

I would recommend that this man be given $25.00 with which to buy beef. This would make an allowance of $75.00 in all.

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.
Ottawa,
December 3, 1943.

Mr. M. Christianson, Gen. Supt. of Indian Agencies,
Dominion Public Bldg., Scarth & Victoria, Regina, Sask.

I have your letter of the 30th ultimo, recommending an additional amount for midday meal purposes at the Sturgeon Lake Day School.

As you state in your letter, we are allowing an amount of $50.00 for the current academic year for this purpose and I note that the school garden has produced a plentiful supply of vegetables which can be used for making soup. I do not see the necessity for purchase of flour and yeast cake.

I would also point out that this year we have forwarded 550 lbs. of the new biscuit to the Sturgeon Lake School. Each of these biscuits weighs 2 ounces and consequently 4400 biscuits were forwarded. The average attendance at this school has been 17 and this means that there are available approximately 270 biscuits for each child. When the formula for these biscuits was prepared the opinion was expressed that they are sufficiently nutritious to dispense with other foods. However, as you are aware, we did not do so but are still allowing the same amount as in previous years.

With the contents of this letter in mind the Department does not see any necessity of increasing the amount.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 107-9-5 of the 3rd instant regarding mid-day meal for the Sturgeon Lake Indian Day School, Carlton Agency.

Personally, since I first entered the Indian work I have always tried to help those who try to help themselves and are accomplishing something for the Indian work. Here is a teacher who is doing a splendid job of teaching, and both he and his wife are interested in the welfare of the children under their care, and then you ask what they are doing with flour and yeast cakes. They are trying to give the children a little change in food and in all probability they are doing what the teachers used to do with the biscuits they had before, that is hand them out to the children just before they start for home at 4.00 P.M. I do not say they were the same biscuits as those given out today but that is how they were used. You must be aware that the feeding of youngsters on the reserves is not what it should be and the only good meal they get in many cases is what they are given at the school. Many Indian Day School teachers have told me that as soon as the Indian children started to go to School they gradually began to gain weight. Also, we know that the reason many of our Indians are suffering from T.B. today is lack of nourishment.

In your letter you mentioned that the school garden had supplied a plentiful crop of vegetables. This is quite true but only through the efforts of the teacher who, instead of going away for the Summer holidays stayed at home to work for just this purpose. I am sure the writer of the above mentioned letter knows what soup tastes like without any meat. However, if you say that we cannot have any meat the children will simply have to do without it.

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.
Ottawa,
December 11, 1943.

Mr. M. Christianson, Gen. Supt. of Indian Agencies,
Dominion Public Bldg., Scarth & Victoria, Regina,

Regina, August 10th, 1946.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I am enclosing herewith requisition for material and labour amounting to $119.53 to be expended in removing an inside wall to enlarge the classroom at the Sturgeon Lake Indian Day School.

The present class-room is very badly crowded and additional pupils should be taken in at the beginning of the new term. The purpose of this expenditure is to reduce the size of the cloak-room and remove an unused staircase, thereby providing floor space for approximately ten more desks.

I would recommend that authority be granted as requested.

J.P.B. Ostrander,

Dear Sir,

You will remember you took my school register when you were here in April.

If you have finished with it, could it be returned? I like to keep the used registers so as to have a complete list of the children's school days.

I know you are busy, and it Returning it very soon.

C. H. C. 12 Nov. 47
may have refreshed your memory.

This year I have an enrolment of over 50.

What about the house?
I have a letter from the Indian Office dated Sept-18, saying the firm would be here on Oct-1 to erect the house. To-day nothing more has been done than just the basement walls.

It is getting late, if we have to stay in the present house it is going to be pretty cold and uncomfortable.
It will be hard to put in the cement floor if it freezes.
I have bought water supplies,
expecting to be in the new house.
I don't want to lose them by
freezing.

I am filling up all the breaks
in the walls and floors so as
to keep out the cold, and will
front part of the house. It will
be very inconvenient, but I suppose
we shall have to put up with it.

Yours Truly,

J.J. Warte

REPORT on the INSPECTION OF BATTLEFORD AGENCY.

From April 1st, 1910, to Sept. 30th, 1911.

The Indians asked for the establishment of a school on the reserve. There are at present 25 children of school age in the band, of whom 17 claim to be Anglicans and 8 Roman Catholics; but their homes are so scattered that it would be necessary to provide a conveyance, as has been done elsewhere.

For this reserve, as well as Moosomin's, provision has been made in the estimates for the teacher's salary and for the erection of a school building; but it was not thought best for this year to make any provision for a teacher's dwelling or a pupils' dining room, until the school takes shape and the requirements are more definitely known.

Respectfully submitted,

Sir,

Referring to that portion of your report in which you deal with the establishment of a school on the new Thunderchild's Reserve I beg to say that you have today been written to in regard to the erection of a building on the Moosomin Reserve. In view of the fact that the Indians on the Thunderchild's reserve are divided as to religion the Department is not prepared at the present time to undertake the erection of a school building. The matter should, however, be kept in mind and reported upon by you again next year.

I have the honour to say that the Thunderchild Indians requested me, when recently making the distribution of Interest money to them, to make the strongest plea possible, so that they might have a Day School on their Reserve. Sir — As I am the missionary in charge at Henderick's and as he asked me to write his letter re the school, for him, I told him I would write a few explanatory remarks on the matter.

There are at least twenty-five children of school age in the Reserve and it is sad to see them growing up year after year in total ignorance. Their future prospect is indeed very poor, both for themselves and also for the government who will have to look after them in the future.

I am told the Chief has been asking repeatedly for a school; even since they moved in to the new Reserve, after the sale of their old one.

It is sad to feel that for another generation at least these Indians will not rise any higher than did the generation before them. I feel this, sir, because myself was at one time exactly like one of these, an ignorant Indian.
unable to speak a word of English, but perhaps I have had better opportunities, and today I can stand on my own feet and will never be a drag on the Canadian government. Why can't other Indian boys attain to a position of self support? All they need is education and that is what the Chief of Thunderchild's so wanting for the young of his Reserve.

Hoping that the department will see their way to supplying a good school to this band.

April 20th, 1913

Superintendent of Department of Indian Affairs

Dear Sir,

I am writing to ask you about a matter which has been on my mind for two or three years past. We have no school in our Reserve and we have many children of school age who ought to be in school.

Yesterday I saw as many members of my band as I could get at, and they are all of one mind that we ought to have a school.

There has been some talk of our getting a school this summer, but it is so uncertain that I think the safest course for me to take is to appeal directly to you, as the children are growing up fast and soon their chance of education will be gone unless something is done at once.

Hoping that you will be kind enough to look after this for me, and thanking you for same in anticipation.

MEMORANDUM

Hon. Dr. Roche -

In the year 1905 the Thunderchild and Mocomin Indians surrendered for sale their reserves near Battleford, and in the year 1909 moved to new reserves which had been allotted to them some 50 miles or so farther north. The majority of the Thunderchild band is Protestant, there being 75 Anglicans, 35 Roman Catholics and 4 Indians of other beliefs, and the majority of the Mocomin Band Roman Catholics.

Since the removal of these two bands the Department in 1912 engaged a teacher for the Mocomin band as well as a field matron, the school being conducted under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church in a building owned by the mission for which the Department pays a rental. No provision, however, was made for the Thunderchild band, but up to the 31st May, 1914, the Battleford Industrial School was available.
for Anglican children and the Thunderchild Roman Catholic boarding school, near the old reserve, is still available for the Roman Catholic children of the band.

The Indians have been pressing for a day school and in view of the closing of the Battleford school it may be said reasonably so.

We have delayed taking action, however, as their locations on the reserve were very much scattered and the success of a day school was problematical. We have reports, now, which would show that the Indians are so situated that the children could reasonably be expected to attend regularly. They are anxious for a day school; this would entail an expenditure for a suitable building, etc., of about $6,000.00, which would have to be provided for by Parliament, as payments from their land sales have been coming in very slowly.

Some time ago I gave careful consideration to the establishment of a day school on the new Thunderchild Reserve. We are increasing the salaries of our teachers in many instances. The need of better salaries to induce more efficient teachers to take up Indian work has been apparent, but where we pay a fair salary we insist upon the appointment of only qualified teachers. We will be prepared to consider each case on its merits.

With regard to the field matron on the Sweet Grass Reserve, I would state for Your Lordship's information that the whole question of field matrons is at present being given careful consideration by our Commissioner, Mr. Graham. I am now old, my hair is grey and I have not long to live. I may ask you for advice etc. on minor matters yet, but I want to make one request of you, which you may find not easy to comply with, but one which I hope you will consider well as it well as a matter upon which I meditate on night and day. I see my grandchildren about me, unable to speak a word of English and I will leave this world with sorrow in my heart if I am unable to leave them something which will do so much towards arming them for the struggle in an ever increasing white environment.

I am referring to the granting of an improved school on the Reserve. I have just held a council meeting and all my people look to me powerless and old and say all is lost. They tell me to do something to get a school for them.

In the treaty I was promised a school within my Reserve, and although I realize the difficulties involved in having our homes up at the lake, some twenty miles away in the first part of the winter, yet the difficulty is not insurmountable. We give you are willing to go far towards meeting you in overcoming any difficulty. We desire a school greatly.

I ask you not to dismiss the matter after the Indian Agent has pointed out the obstacle, for it is his duty to do so. I understand that, but discuss ways and means with us and we will do whatever we can to so arrange things that a school would be not a useless expense.

We now understand what education means, but too late and we see the Boarding Schools are unable to provide, only for a small fraction of the total number of children in these Reserves.

Again Chief Thunderchild thanking you again sincerely for a reply.

Yours sincerely,

Chief Thunderchild

Dear Mr Scott,

Regarding your favor in reply to my letter dealing with a Day School in my Reserve I and my Indians desire to express our appreciation at the kindly way you replied.

I am not in any way trying to show disrespect to our agent, Mr McDonald, or not asking him to write for me. I wrote directly to you because I know that, from because of his knowledge of the day school of the past, he would not be able, in justice to himself, to recommend a school of this character.

Your letter led me to understand that you would do what you can to give us a school to be situated inside the Reserve if, by next summer (1924) funds were not forthcoming to build a Boarding School somewhere in central Saskatchewan.

I am very loth to try to disturb the line of your general policy regarding the education of our young in Western Canada but exceptions are sometimes in order, when conditions justify.

I asked you in my last letter to make such an exception for me, partly because I am the last of the old chiefs who took part in the first treaty. To me then personally was promised a school on my Reserve if I and my people desired it. So we therefore an exception made would be more justifiable than to other chiefs who belong to a later period and who are therefore not so closely connected with the original agreement. To give to my grand children at least one heritage which will be of real and lasting value to them is my one remaining and all-consuming ambition. If I can do this, then I can leave the world in peace. Otherwise I will feel as if my life had been a failure.

To a man, any can and R.C., my people find it very hard to part with their children to have them go to school. It is not that they do not desire to have them educated but they are not favorable to Boarding Schools and I must give you their reasons for this so that you may not think that it is due to some idle fancy. I am not going to touch on the side of sentiment, that part of it you will readily understand knowing the Indian as you do.

A spruce tree taken while young from a low lying moist soil when transplanted to light soil dies in most cases. If it lives, it will be but short and stunted whereas it would have been tall and straight had it been left in its natural soil. It will be like this despite the greatest of care. It is not because it has no capacity for growth, it is because it is taken out of its natural environment where it would have done well. I have no education but my hands are grey. I have seen and observed life, I have learnt the ways of nature and I see that the Boarding Schools and their effect on our young can be explained by this parable. The system is not natural, it seems artificial and the fruit of it so far as I see it on my Reserve and elsewhere has been very poor. Many a pupil has come home to die being in the last stages of consumption. The strict discipline, the change of environment, the close confinement, the different food, has lessened the vitality of our young and made them susceptible to the germs of tuberculosis which the buildings are always in times saturated with which the Boarding School that was in Battleford I learnt this from the Boarding School that was in Battleford when it was taken over by the Seventh Day Adventists they were obliged to pull down almost the whole building because in order to insure against infection from the germs that had played havoc among the Indian children. From the Indians' point of view that school although in very capable and kind worthy hands, was a long history of sorrow because of the disease and death. Then we found that the continual supervision on Sunday work meant the killing of all initiative in the pupils. They came back with good records, knowing English well and other things taught them but they were neither white men nor Indians. They do not seem to know how to make the start. They had lost the ordinary Indian mode of livelihood and were unable to do so the white man did. They were victims of their educational opportunity.
The sense of ownership and the desire to increase what is owned is a thing that should be developed in childhood stage; all this is lost to the child in the Boarding School while there he works at cows' houses, cleans rooms, flows, and helps in housework but he gets nothing in return. I myself know he actually is working for himself, but he does not see it that way. He has no chance therefore to couple work with its reward. This teaches him to look upon work as a drudgery and in many cases this idea persists through life.

There are other reasons I cannot give out these are enough to show that we take the stand we do not unadvisedly but intelligently enough.

As regards day schools - they give us a chance to have the children in our care which is natural.

Secondly, with the improvement in the kind of teachers you give, they will all learn to read, write and figure. Besides they will be taught neatness, cleanliness, and such things - object lessons not only to themselves but also to their parents. With this teaching, they will be as well equipped, all things considered, as the ordinary son of an ordinary homesteader. Besides learning these they will be absorbing from their parents the way of making around for a living which is better than nothing even in the most unfavorable case. This will enable the child to begin life at a plane one or two stages higher than their fathers did.

Secondly, the boy will own a cow or a horse while in childhood. He will learn to till an interest in it and will work for it. This will develop a sense of ownership in him and that means a great deal.

Thirdly, he will be growing up and developing in his own natural element, the process being modified by what influence is exerted on him by the school.

Fourthly - we do not expect the Boarding Schools to half cover the ground. Only a percentage of the children will be accommodated.

I have made inquiries of the school at Little Pines under Archdeacon MacKay. Up to now that school is a wonderful success. In the first time the Improved Day School has been given a fair chance. Such kind of Indians as we are - off a few years ago they were so aptitude about the school that it had to...
Now they are working hard in hand with the teacher because they see results and because they have been made to feel that the school is theirs and that they can close it automatically themselves by not keeping up the attendance. Such a school I desire for most earnestly and so does every member of my band.

We are in a new Reserve after selling our old one. It has meant starting over again and the start has not been too good. I see, as one of the assets needed, a school, so that something may be done to help the next generation.

I called a meeting tonight, most of the band were here. A few unable to attend had told me their feelings on the matter discussed before leaving. We have all learned a lesson after losing our school. We see its value now. We know there are difficulties in the way, in the attendance we have our winter quarters at Little Lake when we want our cattle. I pointed out all the difficulties to them—told them not to promise what they cannot perform. We all desired for a school at all costs. We counted the children of school age and there are 36. We thought 25 would be a fair average to aim at. We are willing almost to a man to go back to what we used to do when we had more cattle to make hay and then instead of all migrating to winter quarters send the young men with one or two older men to oversee them, to the lake to attend to the cattle. We are willing to meet half-way any arrangement that may be made by you and your officials.

One man suggested a room or two to accommodate a child whose parents have to go away and have no place to leave him. That is a detail. What we want is the school. Judge us not in this from the past fate of our school at the old Reserve or from other schools but believe when I say that a new spirit has been born in most Indians with regard to education.

This is no new to a prayer, as anything can be said from man to man. I ask in all good faith.

With my respects,

Yours respectfully,
Chief Thunderchild

THUNDERCHILD'S DAY SCHOOL

This school was just opened this year. It is a log building size 28'x15' and has a chancel 14'x18' attached. It is used for church purposes on Sundays. The building is situated in a central position on the Thunderchild reserve.

Miss Amy D. Wrigley, who holds a Second Class Professional Certificate for the Province of Saskatchewan, has been in charge as teacher since the school was opened. There are 36 pupils enrolled and the average attendance for the Quarter ending Sept. 30th was 26.67. This I consider a very good attendance in view of the fact that quite a number of the Indians of the Thunderchild Band earn their living by hunting and trapping and working out for white settlers, which occupations naturally take them away from their reserve a great deal. They have 30 single desks in the school and if the total enrollment were to attend they would not have sufficient desks to accommodate them. The teacher asked that she might be provided with at least six more. I noted that they had three wash basins and that the pupils were all provided with toothbrushes. The teacher informed me that they were made to clean their teeth regularly each day. They have a Hyloplate blackboard 3'x12'. This does not give as much blackboard space as is desirable and I think that if another board the same size was installed it would be sufficient for the requirements.

With reference to the building; as I have said before it is built of logs and has a shingled roof. It is plastered with mud and should be whitewashed before the winter sets in as I noted the plaster had shrunk and in places there was daylight showing through the walls. It should also be ceiled with lumber, as I am afraid that during the winter months unless this is done it will be hard to heat.// There is no midday meal served at this school, the children being given the regulation issue of hardtack biscuits. I found the teacher very bright and enthusiastic. She is greatly interested in her work and appears to have gained the confidence of the Indians who appear to be very interested in their school.

My Lord:

It is now one year since the Thunderchild's Reserve Day School was opened, with Miss Wrigley as teacher. The Indian Department, at the time promised the teacher's salary and school equipment, providing we found a school building. The Indians of the Reserve who, up to then were always on the move from place to place, began to work in the depth of winter and before the snow was gone had the present large school-church finished, so keen were they to have their children educated. They have up to now, never slackened once in their wholehearted support of the School.

The average attendance since the School was opened on May 15th, 1924 is as follows:

| Month       | Year | Average Attendance |
|-------------|------|--------------------|
| June        | 1924 | 32.65              |
| September   | 1924 | 26.92              |
| December    | 1924 | 29.29              |

My dear Sir:

Re Thunderchild Indian Day School.

With reference to your letter No.105-9-1, of January the 16th last: So far I have not been able to get anyone for the school on Thunderchild's. The combination of a certificated teacher with a wife who is able and willing to do the matron's work, and to go out there while the thermometer is ranging, as ours has been for some time, 20, 30 and 40 below zero, is not an easy thing to be done.

I have a very good man, single, and un-certificated, that I may be able to send out there to carry on the school until he is ready to go into the Normal School and get his certificate in September. But at the present moment I do not see where a married teacher, and a suitable wife, is coming from. I can find them later on in the year, but not at the present time. In addition Thunderchild's Reserve has Mrs. Brown who is continuing her work for the time being until a married teacher can be appointed.

If you are satisfied to have a single man or a single woman for the time being, I can get them.

With kind regards

REGINA, SASK. November 19th, 1929.

Inspector Murison's Report on Schools in the Battleford Agency.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I beg to submit the following report of an inspection which I made of the schools included in the Battleford Agency.

THUNDERCHILD DAY SCHOOL (Anglican)

I visited this school on the 7th instant. I found 13 boys and 9 girls present out of an enrolment of 26. The pupils were clean and healthy looking. I held a brief examination and they answered questions clearly and distinctly, and have a bright appearance.

I found the school room bright and clean. They have very little blackboard space and an addition in this connection would be beneficial.

A mid-day meal of vegetable soup and biscuits is provided. I found the dining room bright and clean.

Since my last visit a new teacher has been appointed, Mr. William Sharman. His wife prepares the mid-day meal for the children. Mr. Sharman appears to me to be a well qualified teacher. He has a nice manner with the children who appear to be quite at their ease with him. Mr. Sharman is a man who is well advanced in years and teaching has been his life profession.

The school buildings have been enclosed with a page wire fence on tamarac posts. The grounds were neat.

W.M. Graham, Esq., Indian Commissioner,

W. Murison

William Sharman. Age 66. Health: apparently quite good although his hearing is getting very poor.

This teacher is slowing up, somewhat, possibly due to his age. I regret to have to report that very little action is taken by this teacher in connection with suggestions left with him. He uses the same old methods that he has probably used for many years and I doubt if it is possible to change him at this time.

I do feel, however, that Mr. Sharman would be well advised to apply for pension as his hearing is becoming so impaired as to hinder him greatly in his work, particularly in the matter of discipline. This, of course, in turn reflects on the other work, and makes it impossible for him to obtain the best results in the school. It is true that his example and influence are all that could be desired in a teacher, but I do feel that the actual work in the classroom is suffering to quite a considerable extent.

I have just been informed, that at a recent visit of the Ven Archdeacon Paul to Thunderchild reserve, that he advised the Teacher Mr W. Sharman to resign as he was too old, he was too old and also partially crippled, when the Church Authorities recommended him for the position and I have reported to the Department to this effect on two different occasions, but what I don't like is Church interference in the schools and back of this is Mrs Brown, local Missionary and late Field Matron, who wants to get a friend in there, Mrs Reid, (Née Miss Wright) who was the best teacher we ever had there, but at the same time she is now married to a man in business and if the position was opened, someone with dependants should get it and there are many capable teachers in want at present.

It has always been the policy of the Department to give the various Churches the recommending of teachers who with few exceptions are selected for their ability as Missionaries and pay more attention to Church requirements than they do to Departmental and practically ignore the Agent and a Catholic at an Anglican day school gets small consideration and vice versa, and in many cases Denominational grievances rife on the reserves from this source.

After all the Department are trying to educate these people and if all day schools were made non-denominational, Teachers employed for their merits and outside interference stepped, the results at most schools would be vastly different, Teachers would take their instructions, be employed or discharged from Departmental sources and would have to confine their activities to teaching school and let the Missionaries do the Missionary work.

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of September 27th enclosing a long letter purporting to be an application for superannuation allowance under The Teachers' Superannuation Act.

In reply I beg to advise you that section 3, which reads as follows:

"3. This Act shall apply to teachers actually employed in teaching or in the supervision of teaching on or after the coming into force of the Act in those schools receiving grants from the Province of Saskatchewan."

will advise you that your application cannot be considered. There was certain correspondence between Bishop Burd and the Honourable J. T. M. Anderson and the reply set out in detail that teachers in Indian Schools, being temporary federal civil servants, cannot be taken care of under The Teachers' Superannuation Act of Saskatchewan. Furthermore, their salaries being paid either by the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa or by the church under whose jurisdiction the Indian School is controlled, they must look to either of these in the matter of allowances in their old age. Section 19 of The Saskatchewan Teachers' Superannuation Act definitely states that four per cent. of all salaries received must be deducted by the secretary of the school district and, in turn, shall be withheld by the Minister from the grant payable to boards of trustees of school districts. You have made no contributions to this fund. Furthermore, section 14 states that any teacher who is absent from the classroom of schools receiving grants from the Province of Saskatchewan for a period in excess of twelve consecutive months voids all claim to service rendered previously for superannuation purposes.

I am, therefore, sorry to advise you that no consideration can be given in the matter of your application.

Yours faithfully,

Teachers' Superannuation Commission

I beg to forward herewith Provincial School Inspector D. L. Hicks' report of an inspection which he made of the Thunderchild Indian Day School on September 23rd. I received this report on October 16th last and held it as I had planned to visit the Battleford Agency before forwarding it, but to date I have not been able to arrange a visit there.

This report indicates a very unsatisfactory condition in so far as the attendance is concerned. When the school was first opened some years ago with Miss Wrigley as teacher, in my opinion, it was one of the most satisfactory day schools from a point of progress and attendance in the Province and it remained as such while Miss Wrigley was in charge as teacher. However since she left the service the school appears to have gone back and I have no doubt that this retrogression can to a large extent be attributed to the personality of the teacher. The Inspector states that the difficulty in this school is apparently lack of interest and co-operation in the homes. I plan to go to the Battleford Agency in the near future and will make a special point of taking up this question with the teacher, the Indian Agent, and the Indian parents, with a view to making an effort to improve conditions.

Your obedient servant,

W. Murison,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF INSPECTOR D. L. HICKS,
DATED SEPTEMBER 23, 1935, ON HIS INSPECTION OF THE
THUNDERCHILD INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

Original on No. 105-9-6.

The pupils present made a fair showing, but as less than 50% were in attendance, it is difficult to state just how definite progress has been.

The difficulty in this school is apparently lack of interest and cooperation in the home, resulting in indifferent attendance with the consequent results in progress. I would suggest that the noon lunch be reinstated by the Department of Indian Affairs, as I believe this stimulates attendance as well as improves the health of the children who are I fear in many cases undernourished.

Both last year and this year attendance was so poor on the date of my visit that I do not feel that I am in a position to commit myself definitely with regard to the progress in the work of the school. There were no failures in the tests given to the pupils present, who numbered five. Written tests were given in language, home economics and spelling, and classes were observed as taken by the teacher in reading. The percentages taken in the tests ran from 55 to 88, and although these marks cannot be graded as high I feel that in view of the fact that the children are only attending part time the teaching must have been fairly effective.

On looking up the register I found that the attendance on this day was no exception. I do feel that this teacher could do quite good work if the pupils attended regularly, and unless something is done to stimulate regular attendance at school, I can only say that the school is not serving the purpose for which it exists.

On looking up my last year's report I find that noon lunch was being served, and that attendance was poor at that time, which points to the fact that its revival might not have the desired result. I still have the feeling, along with the teacher, that it would help to some extent, and certainly it would be very beneficial to those who are in attendance. I cannot urge too strongly on the Department the importance of furnishing some incentive which will stimulate attendance. If this cannot be done I cannot conscientiously report that the school is justifying its existence.

Sir:

Referring to your letter No. 105-9-1, dated the 18th ultimo, with reference to Inspector Hicks' report on his inspection of the Thunderchild Indian Day School, Battleford Agency, on September 23rd, I beg to report that I visited this school on the 28th ultimo and made a careful enquiry into conditions.

While there are 12 pupils enrolled at the present time, 7 boys and 5 girls, there are only 8 children of school age on the Reserve who are physically fit to attend. The average attendance for 20 days in November was 5. On the date of my visit there were 6 in attendance, 4 girls and 2 boys. Five of the pupils appear to attend very regularly. Of the others enrolled, I found that the fault does not lie with the teacher, but rather with the parents who do not reside regularly on the Reserve and take their children with them on their trips. This is a condition for which the teacher cannot be held responsible.

I was quite favorably impressed with Miss Beanland as a teacher. I believe that if she were given a chance she is capable of doing very good work. She has with her as companion a Miss Turner who is also a qualified teacher. After visiting the school and having an opportunity of talking with Miss Beanland and watching her conduct her classes, I am of the opinion that in considering this question it is not a question of dispensing with the services of the teacher but one as to whether the attendance and the prospects for attendance will justify keeping the school in operation.

There are about 39 children of school age belonging to this Band. Of these, 27 are attending residential schools, - leaving 12 -

leaving 12 available for attendance at the Day School. Of these 12 only about 8 are physically fit to attend regularly. If the 8 who are physically fit attended regularly, that is the total attendance we could expect; and the question is whether the Department would be justified in incurring the expense of the upkeep of this school for this number of children.

In discussing the matter with the Indian Agent he appeared to agree with me that it might be in the best interest of the Indians to close this school and send the children of school age to the residential schools. I understand that the Indians for the most part are not averse to sending their children to residential schools.

You ask that I make a definite recommendation regarding the teacher. If the school is to be continued, I have no hesitation in recommending that Miss Beanland's services be continued as teacher. Re Thunderchild Indian Day School. 105-9-1.

Dear Sir:

In regard to your letter of July 15 unless means are taken to increase attendance at the Thunderchild Day School I must agree that the Department is not justified in keeping the school open for the small attendance. It would be much more profitable to transfer the teaching grant to the school at Chitek Lake described in the recent letter of Archdeacon Paul.

The proposed closing of this school brings into the foreground the comparison between the efficiency of Day Schools and Boarding Schools. I presume that if the school is closed the Department will assume the responsibility of educating the children in a Boarding School and as our schools are already full this will be an added reason for building a new school. As you know, the school which burned down at The Pas has not yet been replaced and there are many children who should be attending a Boarding School unless a more definite policy is pursued in regard to the Day Schools.

As you are aware, there are a number of Indian Departmental Day Schools in this Diocese where ample provision is made for the teaching of the children on the reserves, but owing to the fact that children who could attend these Day Schools have been allowed to attend Residential Schools, the attendance has fallen to a point where the closing of the school is considered, and the Department is not only burdened with the cost of maintaining the Day School but is also paying the per capita grant for children who could be and should be taught by the Day School teacher.

Taking as an example the John Smith Reserve near Prince Albert. Here is a compact reserve with efficient school equipment and a first class teacher, the Rev. G. J. Waite. Yet I understand that this year nine of the children are attending the File Hills School and the per capita grant is paid for them in addition to the salary of the Day School teacher.

(Over)
I would suggest that a definite ruling be made by the Department, that where adequate Day School provision is made on any reserve, the children must attend that Day School and will not be sent to Residential Schools except in the case of orphans and other very exceptional circumstances. I do not think that even destitution justifies the taking of children from the reserve but that a grant in aid to the parents would be well spent. In case children from a reserve are sent to a Residential School there should be a strict rule that these must be sent to the school of the religious denomination of the parents. Otherwise we will inevitably have mixed denominations on the reserves and an impairment of the spiritual work amongst the Indians. This is already evident on the John Smith Reserve where some of the children returning from the File Hills School show no interest in the church of their parents and are falling away from religious influence.

I believe that the Day Schools can be made a most efficient means of educating the Indians in reserves where the Indians are residential and if the Department will make plain to the Indians through the agents that they must use existing educational facilities, then I am sure this question of closing Indian Day Schools will cease and we will be able to make those schools more and more efficient.

Perhaps there is already some such ruling which only needs to be brought to the attention of the Indians through the agents. I would be glad to have the considered opinion of your Department on this question.

Assuring you of my cooperation, I am,

Yours faithfully,

In 1937 I visited the Thunderchild Day School and discussed school matters with the teacher. At that time I was not satisfied with conditions and expressed my opinion to the Agent and Dr. Lewis that we should have a change in teachers there. Dear Sir:

What has been done to teach the children:

(a) How to cook meals

Last year the three older girls were given a week at a time, two hours a day at my house, to prepare and cook the children's mid-day meal, and also to learn other little things about a house—cleaning, and ironing, making simple puddings and cookies. After about three months, two of these girls proved to be so dishonest that I had to discontinue it. (One actually stole a ring belonging to Miss Meredith. We recovered it later from quite another source, but it was traced back to this girl.)

When we are able to give them fresh vegetables, the girls prepare them in the school at the noon hour, the day before.

The children always help with the serving out of the meal and lay the table, etc.

When the next group of girls come to be 11-12 years of age I shall give them some cooking experience, etc.

(b) How to sew, etc.

The beginners use sewing cards at first.

Boys and girls have made samples of various simple stitches—basting, running, hemming, backstitch, overswing, French seams, run and fell seams, sewing on buttons, patching.

The older ones also, button holes, gathering into a band, and sewing on bias binding.

The little ones have hemmed towels and handkerchiefs.

Grade 1's and all above, made samples of diamond blocks for quilting, and unbleached cotton bags with simple embroidery design.

Last November they began aprons of unbleached cotton for themselves, some I hope will have a little embroidery later on.

(hh) Knitting

The beginners do spool knitting.

Boys and girls learn plain knitting and purling, first with two needles, and then with four.

Two girls and one boy have made children's sweaters.

Five girls and two boys have made mitts.

Also some of the simpler fancy patterns have been used in making squares suitable for joining together for a bed-throw.

Our present project is to dress a 19 inch doll. Two children have begun a garment each, and others will join as they complete the piece of work they have in hand;

(c) How to look after a garden

Very little has been done by me. When I enquired about arrangements being made to look after a garden during the summer holidays, Mr. Macdonald did not think it advisable to try one at all.

1. The ground is not very good around the school.
2. Our farm instructor, Mr. Cockburn, has done splendid work with regard to the gardens at the homes; most of the people have had good gardens the last two years, those who have taken most interest have been best repaid naturally.

We planted a Caragana hedge at Coronation time and the children kept it weeded last year, but I am afraid it has not done very well so far.

There are two little flower beds between the house and the school, and for two years we tried to grow lettuce and radish, (something that we could use before the end of June). Each child having their own row was the idea, but the birds ate most of it as it came up, and the ground is very poor, so we have planted a few perennials in one plot and caragana bushes in the other.

For Regina Exhibition 1936, we made collections of pressed wild flowers and weeds and leaves and named them all. With the two latter we obtained 3rd prize for each at Prince Albert.

We also made a scrap book on the study of wool and articles made from it, and obtained 1st prize at Regina.

(c) The Indian Agent — Mr. S. B. Macdonald.

I cannot recall any complaint that Mr. Macdonald has ever made to me, nor any special request of that nature. It has generally been that I have asked him to get after certain families because of irregular attendance at school. He has always appeared very agreeable.

On February 23, 1938, Mr. Macdonald and Dr. Lewis visited me at 4 p.m., As they were leaving Mr. Macdonald called me back into the living room and asked me if there was any trouble in the school, and went on to say that Inspector Robertson's report of Oct. 1937 had been discussed while he was in Battleford, and they felt there might be someone interfering with the school. Was Mrs. Brown causing any trouble? Not having seen the 1937 report, I was at a loss to know what they were referring to, but I discussed with him Mr. Brennan's remarks to me re — order and discipline, and told him the reason why I had previously allowed more freedom was because I wanted to make the children like to come to school, etc., but that I had tightened up considerably at the School Inspector's request. And as for Mrs. Brown she certainly did not interfere with the running of the school. He was still of the opinion that Mrs. Brown had given trouble once and might be at it again.

Candidly, when I first came here as "substitute teacher" in May 1934, I expected suggestions and information from Mrs. Brown, and took all she offered. But when I was appointed in Sept. 1934, and came into residence, for quite a long time Mrs. Brown would frequently come into the school at any time of day and tell me to do this or that, or that the children should not be allowed to do this or that — until finally I had to tell her that I was responsible for the school, etc. As far as the Church went I would help her all I could, but that was her responsibility, and I felt the school was mine. Since then we have never had any trouble. So that in 1937 it was certainly not Mrs. Brown who was to blame.

As I said before, I did not see the School Inspector's report sent in Oct. 1937, so I still do not know what they could have had in mind. I only saw the advice quoted to you already.

(d) The Indian Inspector — Dr. T. Robertson.

1. May 1938. Complained about the Anglican Prayer and hymn book being used in the school. This you took up. At present I am using it the same as I ever did. We sing a hymn every morning, and very occasionally if there are no R.C. present I take a little drill in finding places for Church Service, but otherwise use only the Bible stories.

2. On the same visit Dr. Robertson told me to take the children out of school for half a day and tidy up the yard. We had been spending our noon hours for several weeks tidying it up, but it is a very rough piece of ground and does not show much improvement for the work put on it. However we took time off and did the best we could.

3. In Oct. 1937, on his first visit Dr. Robertson was inspecting the children's knitting and sewing, and enquired what was being done for the women along that line. I told him that I did not do anything but that Mrs. Brown had her W.A. and the women did sewing then.
But he seemed to think there should be a definite class when they were given instruction, etc., and the class-room could be closed for half a day and all supplies obtained from the Department.

The following spring when the weather improved I tried to organize something and got together the younger English speaking women. I found I had a little wool that I could spare from the school supply to make a start on and see how we progressed. For the first meeting I closed School one hour earlier, but since then the members come and work in the dining-room, (they enjoy the social time) and when school is dismissed they have the instruction part and take notes in the class-room.

On March 31st 1926, I wrote the following to Mr. Macdonald:

Quote: "Last Fall when you brought Dr. Robertson to visit the school, he was very anxious that some kind of instruction class should be held for the older girls and young women. With the coming of the lighter days I endeavoured to organize a class along that line, and, using what wool I could spare from the class-room, they have been learning to knit gloves and mitts. I have also tried to give them a little instruction in home nursing and the care and use of the medicines supplied. We have had six classes with an enrollment of nine, and average attendance of six. Do you consider this is the type of class Dr. Robertson had in mind? If so, what means is there whereby I can procure some materials for future use?

(I regret that I have omitted to file Mr. Macdonald's reply, I took to Saskatoon with me for reference, and cannot find it just now.) But in it he implied that the class was all right, but it was more on the line of Homemakers Club that Dr. Robertson was thinking.

That Easter when in Saskatoon, I interviewed Miss Rowles of the Extension Dept., Saskatchewan University, and she thought we were making a good start and could be affiliated to the Homemakers Clubs if we wanted. There was such a broad field, and every group had to adapt it and take what was suitable. She gave me some literature from which I have used some suggestions.

The following is an outline summary of our meetings:

1. Learning to make mitts or gloves, in some cases introducing a fancy stitch.
2. Hints on Home Nursing:
   1. Care of T.B. patient in the house (M.S.C.G. card)
   2. List of the medicines in common use (to get the spelling)
   3. Care of medicines and proper use.
   4. Bandaging and compresses, demonstrated and their use.
   5. Treatment of sprains, and figure of eight bandage on foot.
   6. Treatment of severe nose bleed.
   7. Treatment of a dirty wound.
3. We have begun the correct method and use of the sewing stitches with a view to sewing articles.

We spend the last 15 minutes in a game or community singing (alternate). Closing with the National Anthem, followed by a cup of tea.

I must admit there are not as many young women attending as I should like, but those who do come are keenly interested. At present two are kept at home with tiny babies, but they are looking forward to the time when they will be able to bring their babies and come along again.

Six of them have already completed their gloves and were delighted to purchase them at cost-price. So with that money we can buy other material to make up.

My dear Mr. Hoey:

Dr. Robertson has forwarded me a copy of your letter to him of January 5, in which you state that the teacher at Thunderchild Indian Day School should be changed at the end of the current academic year and you ask him to consult me regarding the nomination of a new teacher. As you have been assured by me, I am at all times willing to co-operate in any action which is for the welfare of the Indian schools in this Diocese, but you will remember that in the conference I had with you in your office, it was agreed that before any dismissal was made, I should be informed of the complaint and be given an opportunity of correcting the fault. Should this not have any effect, I would then be quite willing that the teacher whom I had nominated should be dismissed. A memorandum covering this was sent to all teachers, and a copy was sent to you which you acknowledged. In this present case I wish to point out that the first official notice was your letter to Dr. Robertson. The reason given in your letter was the poor attendance at the school, but I am informed by Dr. Robertson that this is only one of the reasons, and that the chief one is non-co-operation in social service work.

In fairness to Miss Beanland I have asked her to submit to me:

1. A copy of the school Inspector's report.
2. A statement of the average attendance for the past three years.
3. Practical work done by the boys and girls.
4. Complaints which have been made, and what has been done regarding them.

I now enclose copy of her letter of January 21, giving all the information asked for. I ask you to note carefully:

1. Inspector's Report — dated October 20, 1938. On this visit there were 23 children present out of a possible 27. In the general comment, which is favorable, it is stated: "It appears that Miss Beanland continues to give good conscientious service." I cannot find any item in this report which would justify the dismissal of the teacher.
2. Average Attendance

The average attendance for the last four months of 1938 is an average of over 75%, and for the first thirteen days of 1939 86%. In an itemized statement for each pupil for 1938, which I have not copied as it involves excessive typing, the percentage of absentees is mostly accounted for by the children being off the reserve with their parents. This is not the fault of the teacher.

3. Practical Work

You will note what has been done here regarding meals, sewing, knitting, gardening, and health education. I think you will agree that a considerable amount has been undertaken in addition to the academic work.

4. Complaints which have been made.

(a) School Inspector:

You will note that there were not so much complaints as suggestions, and that in each case the suggestion was adopted.

(b) Indian Agent:

You will see from this that it is the Indian Agent's impression that Mrs. Brown, the missionary, is interfering with the school. An agreement on this point was apparently reached and Miss Beanland states "since then we have never had any trouble."

(c) Indian Inspector:

It will be seen that Dr. Robertson's suggestions have been carried out as far as possible with the exception of instruction in cooking, which Miss Beanland says was discontinued owing to the pilfering of the children, but they have been taught how to prepare many other things connected with meals, and the teacher proposes to give the next class cooking experience.

It also should be noted that while Miss Beanland is a single teacher, there is a full time farm instructor and his wife on this reserve who should share the responsibility of the manual training.

My dear Bishop Burd:

I have for acknowledgment Your Lordship's letter of the 30th ultimo, in which you express regret at the action taken by the Department with respect to the removal of the teacher now in charge of the Thunderchild Indian Day School.

I must express regret that a misunderstanding seems to have arisen with respect to conditions at this particular school.

Dr. Robertson, in a report to the Department dated May 25, 1938, expressed the opinion that Miss Beanland, while a good teacher, was scarcely the person to make a success of the Thunderchild School. The Department, in a reply to Dr. Robertson dated June 2, 1938, stated:

"We have noted your remarks regarding Miss Beanland, teacher of the Thunderchild Indian Day School.

"Miss Beanland was nominated by the Right Reverend Walter Burd, Bishop of Saskatchewan, Prince Albert, Sask., and on the occasion of your next visit to Prince Albert, I would suggest that you call on the Bishop and discuss with him the situation existing on the Thunderchild reserve."

Dr. Robertson, in one of his regular reports to the Department dated November 14, 1938, stated in part:

"The teacher at the Thunderchild school has every qualification but is not up to the mark and a change should be made there at the end of this year and a married couple taken on, so that some welfare work can be started".

It was my thought that in the interval Dr. Robertson had discussed conditions at the Thunderchild Day School with you and that you were willing that a change should take place. Therefore my letter to Dr. Robertson dated January 5, 1938, was based on this assumption and was written following a report from the Indian Agent, in which Mr. Macdonald stated in part:

"The day school requirements at Thunderchild now are not a one-woman proposition. We have made -

Right Reverend Walter Burd, D.C.M., D.D.,
Bishop of Saskatchewan,
Synod Office,
Prince Albert, Saskatchewan.
have made every effort to overcome this situation and, as far as I can see, the only way out is to make a change at the end of next June and get a married couple there, to do social work as well as the regular teaching".

Dr. Robertson, in reply to my letter of January 5, stated:

"On Tuesday January 10th I went to Prince Albert and discussed school matters with Bishop Burd. Mr. Davis, our agent at Carlton, and Mr. Simpson, our agent at Duck Lake, were in Prince Albert on that date to discuss matters regarding conditions. I took them with me. We had a very pleasant and friendly discussion. I may say that Bishop Burd is prepared to give us 100% cooperation and has agreed to carefully select a married couple to replace our present teacher at Thunderchild for the beginning of the next term."

You can readily imagine how surprised I was to receive your letter of the 30th ultimo. It was not my thought that I had departed in any sense from the agreement reached with you when you visited my office about a year ago - an agreement which was later confirmed by letter. In view of the fact that Miss Beanland appears to be reasonably successful in her classroom work, would it not be possible to have her transferred to another school? I have already intimated, in discussing school matters with Dr. Robertson, that these teachers were not originally employed to undertake instruction in farming or general welfare work on the reserve. Consequently, it has never seemed altogether fair to me to dismiss them for their failure to accomplish work other than the work ordinarily undertaken and accomplished by a teacher.

I am sending forward to Dr. Robertson a copy of this letter and also a copy of the circular sent out by you to your teachers and referred to in the communication. I feel confident that this matter can be easily adjusted by Your Lordship and Dr. Robertson.

Yours very truly,

Dear Dr. Robertson:

I am enclosing herewith, for your information, copy of a letter sent by the Department to Right Reverend Walter Burd, Bishop of Saskatchewan, Prince Albert, Sask.

I am also sending forward copy of a circular dated September 20, 1937, sent out by Bishop Burd to the Indian day school teachers of his diocese. May I direct your attention particularly to paragraphs 1 and 2 of this circular, both of which relate to the employment and dismissal of teachers and both of which were agreed to by the Department here at the time of Bishop Burd's visit.

In view of the splendid cooperation that has existed between you and Bishop Burd with respect to the employment of teachers, I am very sorry indeed that a misunderstanding has arisen regarding the teacher at the Thunderchild School. It is just possible that the transfer of this teacher to another school would be satisfactory to the Bishop and accomplish what you have in mind. In any event I am convinced that the matter can be adjusted.

Dear Sir:

Ref: Your #105-9-1 of February 2nd,
Bishop Burd re Thunderchild Teacher.

I must say that Bishop Burd's letter came as a surprise. At our last interview, I fully explained that while Macdonald's recommendation was made in reply to one from you re attendance, it was on the grounds of lack of progress and failure to carry out suggestions, not lack of attendance, that it was made.

I have kept the Bishop advised of the progress made on the Reserves where the proposed work has been carried on, and at the meeting above referred to, again pointed out to him its effect and consequent necessity. We left the meeting with the understanding that he was satisfied and that a change would be made. In fact, Davis, Simpson and I, after leaving, spoke of the good co-operation the Bishop was giving. It was also on his suggestion that I recommended an increase in salary in order that he could secure the best teacher available.

With regard to the Bishop's intimation that I would not have recommended dismissal had I known conditions, I can only say that I know them too well. If he realized, as I do, that the Church and Department are responsible for those conditions, he would think less of security of tenure and more of the necessity of rectification. He would not leave 150 Indians to suffer in order that a teacher should retain her position.

With regard to his suggestion that the Farming Instructor and his wife should be responsible for this work instead of the Teacher, I would point out that the Teacher has authority to close his school for the purpose of this meeting, consequently he is being paid for that time. Visiting the homes would have to be done after hours, but any man or woman who does not take enough interest in the welfare of the Indian to do this should not be in the service of our Department. In addition, he or she is trained for teaching.

The Farming Instructor is going from six a.m. until dark, if he is doing his own work properly. His wife, however, should assist.

I must admit that I was somewhat irritated when I first read the Bishop's letter, as I have been on several occasions with our Agents for lack of effort to secure the assistance of the Teachers in rectifying conditions, also with a number of the Teachers for the uninterested way in which they received suggestions. This, however, subsided after reading the Bishop's circular, approved by the Department, and I now believe I owe the Bishop and the Teachers an apology for attempting in.......

attempting in any way to direct their efforts.

This circular clearly informs the Teachers that their position is secure so long as they carry out his instructions. It does not definitely state, but the inference is there, that they may disregard the Agent, the Inspector or even the Department's instructions with safety. True, it provides that if the Department is not satisfied, they may so inform the Bishop, who will then advise the Teacher. Then, if the Teacher does not rectify conditions, dismissal may follow. The Bishop, however, makes it perfectly clear in his letter that the School Inspector only shall be the judge of their efficiency.

I can now understand the attitude of the Teachers, and our Agents, and when I remember conditions on Montreal Lake, the protest that was made about that change, the fact that the Teacher who was at that time dismissed for inefficiency was within two months sent to Battleford with a recommendation from the Bishop for the position of Teacher on the Red Pheasant Reserve, I can but sympathize with the Indians under present arrangements.

I am fully in accord with the idea that an employee's duties should be outlined to him when he comes on, and I am now informing all applicants for positions of Farming Instructor, that in addition to their own duties, their wives will be expected to organize and carry on Home Makers' Clubs or similar organizations.

I would, however, point out that at present about the only work that is being carried on on our Reserves is a little grain growing and cattle raising. These activities must be extended to cover hogs, chickens, turkeys, raising horses, growing fruits, or anything we can find that will give the Indian food or revenue. It would therefore be ridiculous to say a Farming Instructor could not be dismissed if he refused to instruct and assist the Indians in hog raising or any other line, on the ground that that was not one of his duties when he took the position.

What we need on our Reserves today is not time servers, or people who object to carrying on work not outlined to them when they were engaged, but men and women constantly seeking for new ways and means to advance the Indian, ready to co-operate and assist in every way possible. There is no difficulty in securing such men and women. Then why should our work and the Indian suffer to keep a white man or woman in a position when they refuse to co-operate?

You suggest that I should see the Bishop again on this matter. With regard to this, I would point out that I have gone fully into the work we are carrying on and the progress that has been made. He has had ample time to consider the matter and to verify the truth of my statements. I have invited him to go along with me as my guest, visit the reserves, and see for himself the improvements made. I have asked for his co-operation and assistance. I explained to him fully our reasons for asking a change of Teachers at Thunderchild, and was informed that the change would be made.

I pointed out to him the poor report on the Teacher in the Church of England School at Onion Lake, and suggested Miss Beanland be transferred there, as I did not believe the present Teacher would be retained with such a report.

A few days after this, the Bishop writes you, objecting to Miss Beanland's dismissal on the grounds that her services were satisfactory, basing his statement on the School Inspector's Report, and at the same time stating that the work we were asking Miss Beanland to carry on was the Farming Instructor's duties.

Only one conclusion can be drawn from the above. The Bishop has now decided that his Teachers shall only carry on class work, that the School Inspector shall be the judge as to their efficiency, and that the Agent or Inspector have no jurisdiction or right to require the Teacher to do anything.

Under the above conditions, I feel that it would not only be useless for me to again discuss this matter with him, but also that he would resent my doing so.

It is therefore my intention to discontinue all efforts to enlist the Teachers in this work. It is a work that I consider vitally necessary, so I shall endeavour to persuade our Farming Instructor's wives to organize and carry it on.

I would, however, point out that most of these women have children to care for in addition to their housework. It will therefore be very difficult for some of them unless we can make them an allowance in order that they may keep a maid.

I would therefore recommend that serious consideration be given by the Department to the question of reducing our Teachers' salaries to $550.00 per year.

In support of this, I would point out that many of our Teachers in Saskatchewan are now only receiving $350.00 to $450.00 per year. We could secure all the teachers we want for $500.00, consequently there should be no just complaint on the part of the public if we reduced ours to $550.00. In fact, if the public knew conditions and that this service could not otherwise be given, I think we would be severely censured if we did not.

To Dr. McGill

Report on Thunderchild Day School

I visited the above mentioned school on October 8th last. The school is a log building with shingled roof, and in very good state of repair. It consists of the classroom, a room at the back that is used as a kitchen, and a lean-to which is used as a sewing and dining room. There is also a storehouse a short distance from the school, and the teacher's residence which is a four-roomed bungalow. This building is practically new and in good shape. Although small, it answers the purpose for which it was intended, as the teacher and his wife have only one young child. The only repairs that are anticipated for this school is a new floor, as the present one is becoming badly worn. However, it will probably last for another year or two.

The average attendance at this school is about 20. I found there were a number of children from this Reserve attending Boarding Schools, in fact I heard that the Principal from the Onion Lake Anglican Residential School was on the Reserve at the time of my visit. However, I did not meet him. I cannot see why children from this Reserve need to be sent to a Boarding School as there is ample room for them in the classroom.

Mr. A.C.M. Palmer is the teacher and personally, I think he is doing splendid work. Mrs. Palmer assists her husband with the work and it might be interesting to the Department to note that this Day School was 3rd in the prizes received at Regina and Prince Albert during the Exhibitions. Only two Boarding Schools received more money. Mr. Palmer also teaches a little manual training.

Taking everything into consideration, I was pleased with conditions in general at this school and the children all looked very well. I am sure Mr. and Mrs. Palmer should be complimented on the good work they are performing.

Yours truly,

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Agencies.

I am in receipt of your letter of the 10th instant in which you advise that Mr. A.C.M. Palmer, teacher of the Thunderchild Indian Day School, will give up duties on April 15. It is presumed, from your letter, that he is joining one of the branches of the armed services.

Under these circumstances the Department accepts his resignation effective on the date mentioned. As you are aware, the teachers for this school are nominated by the Bishop of Saskatchewan and consequently Mr. Palmer should take up the matter of re-employment after the war with Bishop Martin. The Department is quite willing to endeavour to find employment after the war for teachers now in our employ and who enlist, but necessarily we cannot guarantee that they would be employed at the same school at which they are now engaged.

I am communicating with Bishop Martin regarding the employment of Mrs. Palmer.

Yours truly,

T.R.L. MacInnes,
Secretary.

Mr. M. Christianson,
Gen. Supt. of Indian Agencies,
Dominion Public Bldg.,
Searth & Victoria,
Regina, Sask.
April 15, 1942.

Dear Sir:

I have just heard from our missionary on Thunderchild's Reserve that Mr. A. Palmer, our teacher on that Reserve, has enlisted, and left the Reserve yesterday. Mr. Palmer has not written to me himself but I understand he has notified Mr. Ostrander in Battleford and he has also written to Regina.

In the letter our missionary makes the suggestion that Mrs. Palmer be allowed to carry on the teaching in the school until the end of the term. I understand Mrs. Palmer is willing to accept this responsibility. I also understand she is a teacher holding a first class certificate of Saskatchewan. Therefore, in view of the difficulty of obtaining teachers at the present time, I nominate Mrs. Palmer for this vacancy and ask that she be allowed to continue teaching until the end of the term. This will give us time to look around in the hope of securing a teacher and also prevent any breaking of continuity in the teaching of the school.

I am,

Faithfully yours,

Right Reverend Sir:

On the recommendation of Mr. Christianson, it has been decided to transfer Mrs. R. D. Ross from the Red Pheasant to the Thunderchild Indian Day School, to succeed Mrs. A.C.M. Palmer who gave up duties at the end of June. Our officials feel that Mrs. Ross will carry on the good work that Mrs. Palmer has been doing at Thunderchild. Besides, I am advised that the farming instructor and his wife who live on the Thunderchild Reserve will work well with Mrs. Ross.

As this move appears to be in the interest of all parties concerned, I feel certain that you will approve.

This will leave a vacancy at the Red Pheasant Indian Day School. I would appreciate your nominating a qualified teacher to take charge of this school for the academic year 1942-43.

Ottawa, February 5, 1929.

Sir,

I have to inform you that the Anglican Church authorities have nominated the services of Mrs. Reed (nee Wrigley) as teacher of the Thunderchild Indian Day School. The Department is approving of her temporary appointment for the balance of the present school year, with salary at the rate of $100 per teaching month. Rev. Archdeacon Paul, Prince Albert, who forwards her nomination, is being requested to arrange with Mrs. Reed to take up duties as soon as possible. I shall be pleased if you will give her every assistance you can in her work at this school.

We have informed the Church authorities that it will not be necessary to take any action in obtaining the services of a field matron for the balance of the present school year.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Ottawa, March 7, 1929.

Sir,

I have to inform you that the Church authorities of the Diocese of Saskatchewan have nominated Mr. and Mrs. William Sharman for the positions of teacher and field matron, respectively, on the Thunderchild Reserve. The Department is approving of their appointments from the 1st of April, next. Mr. Sharman has a second class permanent certificate for the Province of Saskatchewan, and has had several years' teaching experience. The salary allowed Mr. Sharman will be at the rate of $40 per teaching month, and Mrs. Sharman, who will perform field matron's duties, will receive $40 per month for the 12 calendar months in the year.

We have requested the Church authorities to arrange with Mr. and Mrs. Sharman to begin duties on the date above mentioned, and I have to request that you will give them every assistance you can upon their taking up duties. Please inform the Department later of the date these new incumbents begin their duties on the Thunderchild Reserve. You should inform Mrs. Reed, who is teaching temporarily, of the above appointments and that her services will not be required after the date they arrive to take up duties.

Your obedient servant,

The Department is advising Archdeacon Paul that Mr. Ball's resignation is accepted and the temporary appointment of Miss Beanland is approved. She will be allowed salary at the rate of $85 a teaching month. Miss Beanland is stated to hold a Second Class Permanent Saskatchewan Certificate and has had eight years' experience. Please give her every possible assistance.

You should advise me as soon as possible the exact date on which Rev. Mr. Ball gives up duties at the Thunderchild Day School and also the date on which Miss Beanland begins duties. This information is required before we can prepare the pay list for the month of May.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

S. L. Macdonald, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Battleford, Sask.

Sir:
