INSPECTION OF INDIAN AGENCIES
REGINA, SASK. August 2, 1938.

Dear Sir:

Re: Battleford Estimates, 1938-39,
Thunderchild Day School.

I have a letter from Mr. Macdonald, Agent, asking for authority to expend the sum of $60.00 on repairs to the above School and Residence.

This is a log building and requires re-plastering each year, also interior whitewashed, Pipes and stoves overhauled and toilets redug and moved.

The Residence also needs a screen door, some repairs to shed floor and the interior kalsomined and floors painted. This last can be done by the Teacher, so only the material would be required.

It might be necessary to have a regular Carpenter for one day to fit screen doors and do some repairs to desks, but other than this all the labour would be done by the Indians. The material would cost approximately $25.00 and the labour $35.00.

I would recommend that authority be given to have this work done.

Yours truly,

Thos. Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

The Secretary,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

TR/FMc
August 6th, 1938.

EX'D.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 2nd instant, you may authorize an expenditure of $60.00 for repairs at the Thunderchild Day School.

It is noted that this amount will cover the cost of both material and labor.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division

Thos. Robertson, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,

Dear Sir:

I have your letter No. 302011A, Feb. 20th, re Bishop Bird's application for a school at Thunderchild reserve, we have a school there and it was built for a school and not a Church, I knew the circumstances well but we dug up old documents to verify my statement and am attaching the Resolution etc. for your information.

The Bishops statement struck me as odd, when we have letters from his office within the month, re getting a surrender for two acres for a church.

The Indians of this band are about 50-50 Anglican and R.C. and latter half did not vote their money for an Anglican church but for a school but had no objection to it being used for a church, so the Anglican Church built a little addition on the end for a chancel and put folding doors which can be opened when it is used for church, there was never any surrender but it was built on reserve lands for a school for Band purposes and an apparent attempt to now claim it as an Anglican church is all wrong.

This school will do for school purposes for some years to come yet, it has a good lean to dining room and is not by any means overcrowded. The cottage residence is small and in the event of a family taking this as teachers it might require an addition.

I trust that this information, with the attached resolution, etc., will clear the situation.

Yours truly,

(Sgd.) S. L. Macdonald,
Indian Agent,

I am enclosing a resolution of the Thunderchild Band, taken at their request at a meeting on their reserve on Feb 7th, Voting $250.00 for the building of a School House on the Reserve.

They have taken out a set of Pine Logs and are now hauling them in to the reserve, it is estimated that it will cost $500.00 for lumber for Flooring and roof, the Church are putting up half and the Indians the other Half and the Indians are certainly showing great enthusiasm over the prospect of getting a school.

I might add that I have had no Official word of a school at Thunderchild, but the Rev Edward Ahenakew, who has taken over the Missionery work in this district has shown me letter from the Bishop, stating that the Dept would pay a teacher if a school house was available.

Work is being started at once on the building and if the Department allows the amount asked on the resolution, I would request that an accountable cheque for the amount be sent me.

Sir:

I have your No. 1020-133 of the 18th instant, enclosing a resolution of the Thunderchild Band with reference to the Thunderchild Indian Day School. I have noted that the Church and the Indian Band are erecting a building for school purposes. I have to inform you in reply that the Department promised His Lordship the Bishop of Saskatchewan classroom equipment and teacher's salary, if he could arrange with the Band for a suitable building. Your letter was the first intimation that the Department has had concerning the effort of the Indians themselves.

An accountable cheque for $250 is being directed to you, under separate cover, and you should use it for the purpose of securing materials for the new building. 14th May, 1940.

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing herewith requisition for needed expenditure for the Thunderchild's Day School.

It may appear that this requisition is large, particularly in view of the fact that we have been advised that these expenditures must be kept down, but I would like to point out that the buildings and premises of this school have been badly neglected in the past and are in wretched condition.

Regarding bolts and screws for repairing the desks I would say that the desks are all loose and falling apart for want of screws and bolts and the teacher will do the necessary work if the bolts and screws are supplied. $2.00 will cover this work.

New wash stands have been made by the children, as part of the boys' manual training and these should have galvanized tin to cover them. The boys will do the work. $3.00 will cover this.

The eaves troughing is for one side of the school building, to be used to collect rain water for the school washing of dishes, floors etc. If the amount of $5.00 is allowed to purchase the troughing the teacher says he will perform the work.

The toilets at this school are in bad condition and need to be moved, also the doors and seats need repairing. $10.00 will be needed for this as there will be some considerable amount of digging to be done.

Regarding the items for whitewashing and cleaning and repairing the fence, amounting to about $35.00 in all, while not absolutely necessary, these jobs should be done for the appearance of the school and grounds.

A cupboard is badly needed for the dishes, pots and pans used for the mid-day meal. $3.00 will cover the cost of the material for this and the boys of the school will do the work as part of their training.

Ottawa, August 21, 1942.

Dear Sir:

I am sending forward herewith requisition for certain school supplies for the Thunderchild Indian Day School. This requisition, you will note, is signed by yourself and by the teacher.

You are authorized to purchase the supplies, other than those marked in red, which have been purchased here and will be sent forward in due course.

May I point out, however, that requisitions from this school in recent years have always contained requests for one wash tub and 4 brooms. While it is the policy of the Department to do everything humanly possible to encourage cleanliness on the part of our Indian day school teachers and pupils, we find it difficult to persuade ourselves that it should be necessary to use up 4 brooms and one wash tub annually. I have learned from experience that the average civil servant in Ottawa can keep his own home reasonably clean with one broom a year and one wash tub every 5 or 6 years. As a matter of fact, we have reached a stage in our development when the public funds at our disposal will not enable us to make such purchases without the closest possible scrutiny, and Indian day school teachers should be informed of this fact.

You might return this requisition in due course.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Encl.

Mr. J.P.B. Ostrander,
Indian Agent,
